title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: vision-carbon-neutral-future
story: East Lothian Council has produced a map of how it sees the new under-construction town of Blindwells and surrounding communities transform as the county tackles climate change.And the hope is that as the country comes out of the Covid- crisis, more people who have been exploring their surroundings as they worked from home or were furloughed will take part in a public consultation on its vision and embrace the concept of ldquomy space as they move forward.East Lothian Council is petitioning the Scottish Government to extend the National Development status it gave the former Cockenzie Power Station site in its National Planning Frameworkdocument to a wider area in their planned revised frameworkwhich is under reviewThe map is part of a wide-ranging consultation which will be launched on the councilrsquos consultation hub on Monday and tackles everything from the environment to travel, leisure and geothermic and renewable energy.It considers how the council can take the opportunity of creating a new town at Blindwells to look at the latest technology and reducing the town and surrounding areas carbon footprint.Among the ideas up for discussion is using groundwater from the area to create waterways and how they can be used to create geothermic energy projects.Project leader Douglas Proudfoot said the idea behind the new water features across the area was to avoid putting pipes underground to remove groundwater and utilise it instead as the new town of Blindwells develops on the former opencast coal site of the same name between Longniddry and Tranent. The firrst houses are due to be built later this year.He said: ldquoWe have a unique opportunity here with a blank canvas for a new town at a time when climate change is central to policies.ldquoI also think the Covid- pandemic has driven forward the idea that people can work from home and find alternative ways to work with the support of digital technology.Central to the vision is alternative ways to travel with an emphasis on walkways and cycle routes.A new train station at a central hub within an area the council has dubbed Greater Blindwells will provide additional access to public transport.To the north of the central hub between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry there are proposals for a water park or outdoor leisure area with the potential to create a lido, space for kayaking and other water sports.At the former Cockenzie Power Station site, less than half-a-mile away, a new centre of excellence is proposed described as a training school and ldquoexemplar development in modular manufacture and construction.The council is launching an eight-week consultation on their vision for the area from tomorrow and people will be able to go in and give their views.They are also hoping that as lockdown restrictions ease they may be able to have outdoor exhibitions for people who cannot access the proposals online and will be advertising the consultation locally so people can get in touch through the post.The Scottish Government is currently looking at revising its framework and the council has made its case for the wider area to be classed as a National Development, which will give their proposals support at a national level.The consultation will open at https:eastlothianconsultations  from Monday, June .

title: water-lovers-paradise-look-new-plans
story: A water park, with the opportunity to swim and kayak, is part of the proposals revealed by the local authority with a series of images also unveiled.The proposed ClimatEvolution Zone would cover the under-construction town of Blindwells and surroundingcommunities stretching from Prestonpans to Longniddry and inland to Tranent and Macmerry.East Lothian Council is petitioning the Scottish Government to extend the National Development status given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in its National Planning Frameworkdocument to a wider area in its planned revised framework which is under review.This could pave the way for the creation of the ClimatEvolution Zone which could transform the area over the next  years through innovative approaches to development.A public consultation on the vision has been launched by the council and breaks the plans down into dferent themes from environment to travel.It asks people to give their views on its approach to a wide range of issues including access and movement the water environment culture, heritage and leisure greenspace and bioersity strong communities and regeneration and enterprise.However, the vision has already come under fire from Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council which branded it ldquocomplex and unclear.The community council warned that the launch of a new vision for the area three years after the local authority produced its Cockenzie Masterplan document ndash which it has never adopted ndash would leave the public with no confidence in the planning system.East Lothian Council paid consultants to produce the Cockenzie Masterplan for the former Cockenzie Power Station site, which it owns, after a series of public consultations in  but the report remains an informal ldquovisionary document.Now the former power station site could be merged into the new ClimatEvolution Zone with no reference to the original masterplan.Bryan Hickman, community council chairman, said: ldquoThe community council are very concerned by the documents recently published by the council."We understood that the changes required for NPF related to the former power station site."The y report now extends to Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Blindwells as well as the power station site."Whilst some of the objectives are to be welcomed, the overall content is complex and unclear and includes such a large area as to be unmanageable in its detail.ldquoThe existing communities have been consulted on the power station site and the result was a masterplan commissioned by the council but not adopted by them."We have submitted this masterplan to be included in NPF."A number of consultations have taken place in our area and they have come to nothing."The feeling is the residents have lost confidence in the system.Neighbouring Prestonpans Community Council also raised concerns about the consultation.Brian Weddell, chairman, questioned whether the proposed train station in the new plan would ever happen, saying: ldquoThere has been no meaningful consultation with local communities who all have concerns about the impact of this development on their communities.The new consultation is based around a study, drawn up in partnership with East Lothian Council, the Scottish Government, The Lothian Drainage Partnership, SEPA, Scottish Water and Scottish Natural Heritage.It considers how the council can take the opportunity of creating a new town at Blindwells and harness the latest technologies to reduce the arearsquos carbon footprint.Among the ideas up for discussion is using groundwater at Blindwells to create waterways and using natural geothermic energy to heat the outdoor water features.Douglas Proudfoot, project leader, said the idea behind the new water features was to avoid putting pipes underground to remove groundwater and utilise it instead as the new town of Blindwells develops on the former opencast coal site of the same name between Longniddry and Tranent.The first houses are due to be built later this year.He said: ldquoWe have a unique opportunity here with a blank canvas for a new town at a time when climate change is central to policies."I also think the Covid- pandemic has driven forward the idea that people can work from home and find alternative ways to work with the support of digital technology.Central to the vision is alternative ways to travel with an emphasis on walkways and cycle routes.A new train station at a central hub within an area the council has dubbed Greater Blindwells will provide additional access to public transport.To the north of the central hub between Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry there are proposals for a water park or outdoor leisure area with the potential to create a lido with space for kayaking and other water sports.At the former Cockenzie Power Station site, less than half-a-mile away, a new centre of excellence is proposed described as a training school and ldquoexemplar developmentin modular manufacture and construction.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the ambitious strategy.He said: ldquoThe Cockenzie and Blindwells sites are adjacent to one another and it has always been inevitable that their development will be closely linked, so it makes sense to seek to extend National Development status to Blindwells.ldquoThe whole area offers unique potential to transform these former industrial sites into places where people can live and work in a sustainable way.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, also welcomed the project which will lsquointeractrsquo with neighbouring communities.He said: ldquoThe area is a far wider community and cannot be seen in isolation.The inclusion of adjacent communities is therefore essential.Councillor Norman Hampshire stressed the proposals are not a lsquofinalised masterplanrsquo but rather a ldquohigh level document which sets out an ambitious vision for the area over the coming  years.He said: ldquoItrsquos an exciting opportunity to ensure that one of the key areas of East Lothian, is developed in an innovative way."Itrsquos not all about whatrsquos new, though."We are looking at enhancing the existing local environment and making the most of the arearsquos unique history as well as its mining and agricultural heritage and the site of the Battle of Prestonpans.The council launched its eightweek consultation on its online hub on Monday.The Scottish Government is revising its National Development Planning Framework which gives an overview of what it wants to see develop on key sites across Scotland.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoWe are grateful for the many views and ideas received in response to early engagement on National Planning Framework  .Our analysis of the responses is underway and will continue over the summer, and we expect to publish an update in the autumn.The council consultation can be found at eastlothianconsultations

title: work-resumes-offshore-windfarm-neart-na-gaoithe-connections
story: Neart na Gaoithewindfarm will be erected in the outer Firth of Forth, about  kilometres north of Torness Power Station, near Dunbar, and be made up of  turbines.The windfarm is due to be completed in , with work now under way onshore for the grid connection.Work on the pound. billion project had ground to a halt due to the coronavirus.Now, residents in the East Lammermuir villages have been alerted to work starting again.The marine cable linking the offshore wind turbines to the National Grid will come ashore at Thorntonloch.A new substation will be built near Innerwick with the onshore grid connection coming at Crystal Rig Windfarm in the Lammermuir Hills.Matthias Haag, project director, sent out a letter highlighting that work was due to restart.He said: ldquoHealth and safety is at the forefront of what we do and I want to assure you that, as well as strictly following the Scottish Government guidance, and in particular physical distancing, all workers have been instructed to travel directly to the sites and avoid using any local amenities unless absolutely necessary.ldquoInitially, we will only have a few people on site to put in place control measures so the rest of the team can start work safely later that week.ldquoOnce thatrsquos happened we will have a reduced workforce on site, including essential supervisory staff.ldquoThe arrangements we have put in place will be under regular review as we continue to closely monitor Covid- and follow the Scottish Governmentrsquos guidance.

title: postal-workers-gather-applaud-edington-staff
story: Residents on St Baldredrsquos Road cheered the Royal Mail workers and the Edington nurses, who waved from the hospital doorway.Royal Mail delivery office manager Paul Howson said: ldquoThese nurses are the backbone of our country and are putting their own lives in jeopardy every day going to work we cannot thank them enough.The local posties are known for going that extra mile to help others.A video posted on Facebook two weeks ago showed their vans pulling up to deliver a bundle of birthday presents to Mr Howsonrsquos daughter Keira, aged , at home during lockdown.Mr Howson said: ldquoShe messaged me that night to say it was the best birthday ever. Irsquom not going to lie, I was a bit emotional myself ndash I had to sneak away round the corner!ldquoIt just shows how much of a team they [the postal workers] are.ldquoWhen I mentioned doing it [delivering the presents to Keira], one of them ed from Gullane to help, one came back from Athelstaneford, just to do that, then went back out to finish their delivery.ldquoThey have been so flexible since the start of the pandemic ndash theyrsquove had to make all sorts of changes.ldquoPeople are doing afternoon shts, who never normally would people are coming in at am who would never normally start till half seven, to adhere to social distancing.ldquoI feel the whole community has come together.ldquoThe generosity and behaviour of everyone in the town towards the postal workers right now is amazing.ldquoSome of us are getting gts, all the supportive signs in peoplersquos windows, itrsquos great.The North Berwick postal staff have also donated three bags of soap, toothpaste and other toiletries to the Edington.

title: drive-give-open-golf-legends-the-recognition-deserve
story: Stevie Hill, captain of Musselburgh Old Course Golf Club, wants to see game legends David lsquoDeaconrsquo Brown, Bob Ferguson and Jack White remembered in the townrsquos graveyard at Inveresk.While out for his daily exercise during the Covid- lockdown, he noticed there were grave markers for Mr Ferguson, a three-time Open champion, and Mr White, but no headstones.He also wants to properly recognise Mr Brown, who is buried there too.He said he was keen that headstones with details of their victories be installed, as a reminder of their sporting prowess on the links and their connections with Musselburgh, which is known as lsquothe cradle of golf rsquo.A social media plea put him in touch with relatives of Mr Brown and Mr Ferguson but, so far, hehas been unable to locate the family of Mr White, who was born at Pefferside, near Whitekirk, in  and died in Musselburgh in , aged .He is best remembered as the winner of the  Open Championship at Royal St Georgersquos.Mr Hill, a member of the Society of Hickory Golfers, said he was anxious to get their permission before launching a GoFundMe online page in a bid to raise funds to purchase and install the headstones.Mr Ferguson, who was born in Musselburgh in  and died in the town in , won a hat-trick of consecutive titles at the Open Championship in  ,  and .In addition to the three Open wins, he posted top- finishes seven times.He became Custodian of the Links at Musselburgh and taught the boys of Loretto School how to play golf.Mr Brown, who born in Musselburgh in  and died, aged , at Inveresk in , won the  Open Championship and finished second in the  US Open.In total, he had  top- finishes in major championship tournaments.Mr Hill explained that it would cost around pound for each of the three headstones, with additional costs for their installation in the cemetery.He said: ldquoMany youngsters learned to play golf at the Old Course, which attracts visitors from all over the world. I want to give these three golfers the recognition they deserve.The cemetery is also the last resting place of famous Open Champions Willie Park Snr, the first to lt the coveted title in  at Prestwick, going on to become a four-time Open champion, and his son Willie Park Jnr, both from Wallyford.In , Musselburgh Town Council, with the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club, erected a stone to mark Willie Park Snrrsquos grave.This, and Willie Jnrrsquos wall-mounted stone, were cleaned and re-lettered with help from the Old Musselburgh Club in .The only Open champion whose grave is as yet undiscovered is that of their relative Mungo Park, who won in , coming from a career as a seaman to have his name inscribed on the Claret Jug.No burial marker has yet been found for him.He and Mr Brown were residents at the Inveresk Combination Poorhouse in the last years of their lives, although when Mr Brown lived there it would have been known as Wedderburn House.Willie Park Snrrsquos great grandson, Mungo Park, praised Mr Hillrsquos efforts, saying: ldquoI am glad to hear that Musselburghrsquos golfers continue to take pride in their history.ldquoThe town deserves recognition for the huge contribution that it made to the history of the game in the th century, when it was both the lsquocradle of golf rsquo and its driving force.He added: ldquoMusselburgh professionals were among the first to take the game to the rest of the world.ldquoIt is fitting that all of the six Open Champions who lived in the town should be properly recognised. ldquoThese six exceptional golfers won  Open Championships between them but there were many others from the town who contributed much to the game and won signicant competitions throughout the world.ldquoMusselburghrsquos golf had strength and depth.ldquoI hope that this renewed interest in Musselburghrsquos Open champions and its history will continue to grow, so that the town can make the most of its reputation, and benefit from its unique place in golf history.

title: diamond-couple-toast-special-anniversary-garden-party
story: Pat and Ian Anderson have lived in the town since  and celebrated  years of marriage on May .Pat, , was born in Turton, Lancashire, and Ian, , is from Kilmarnock.The pair met at a dance in Kensington Town Hall while they were both working in London: Pat at Williams  Glynrsquos Bank and Ian for the civil service.The couple married in London on May ,  and have three children ndash Carol, Jan and Chris ndash and four grandchildren: Christopher, Lindsay, Art and Rudi.Ian is a keen walker and cyclist, often taking journeys from North Berwick to Kingston and Yellowcraig.Pat not only enjoys gardening and keeping fit but is also a sociable person who enjoys spending time with her family and friends.Daughter Carol said: ldquoOriginally we were going to book a meal at Osteria for extended family and friends but that was not to be.The couple celebrated instead with a tea party in their garden at Marmion Road.Carol said: ldquoBoth enjoyed a glass of champagne with scones on the day.

title: students-tour-preston-lodge-high-school-homes
story: Pupils are due toto Preston Lodge High School on August , following the summer holidays and coronavirus lockdown.Now, a short video has been created for those students leaving P behind and moving up to secondary school.The video, included in the schoolrsquos electronic newsletter PLus, allows people to look behind the doors of the Prestonpans secondary school.The newsletter notes: ldquoAs part of the launch of our P transition programme, we have provided all P students and their families with a virtual tour of our school building.ldquoMany thanks to Sarah Lusk [support for learning] for the great job that she has done.ldquoWe thought that some of our older PLers might enjoy revisiting the school that we are all missing!Watching the video allows potential pupils the chance to get their bearings and find dferent departments.Jonny Else, depute headteacher at the secondary school, told the Courier: ldquoIt is part of the transition programme because the pupils cannot physically be in the building just now.ldquoWe are trying to get them more comfortable about the surroundings and a lot of the feedback we have had from P pupils is they want to know where everything is in the school.A further video highlighting dferent departments is also being created.Mr Else added: ldquoThe building is probably more than double the size what they are used to and there are so many dferent rooms and departments.ldquoThe video is to make them feel as relaxed as they can in this dficult time.He added it was not just for future pupils at the school. Preston Lodge alumni can also refamiliarise themselves with their former secondary school.To view the video, go to www.edubuzz.org prestonlodge    p_transition_

title: musselburgh-sea-cadet-named-one-9-000-ordinary-heroes
story: In addition to being the officer-in-charge at Musselburgh Sea Cadets, Chris Gay, , is a busy ambulance control officer with the Scottish Ambulance Service.He said: ldquoI deal directly with Covid- patients as well as medical professionals across Scotland and my job is make sure the patients get the care they need as quickly as possible.ldquoI love being part of the service.ldquoEvery call is dferent and every call is a person needing help. I love to make sure they receive the first step along the way to getting the right patient care.He added: ldquoItrsquos helped my people skills which has also helped me within sea cadets.ldquoI was quite quiet when I started which is unusual for sea cadets.ldquoWhen you work with so many people, it brings you out of yourself and itrsquos definitely taken me out of my comfort zone.Eighty-five per cent of sea cadet activities at unit level are taking place lsquovirtuallyrsquo despite the loss of hugely popular inshore and offshore boating programmes, competitions and the international exchange programme.Sea Cadets remains an important part of many young peoplersquos lives with nearly , cadets nationwide. During lockdown, the impact of its volunteers on their lives hasnrsquot stopped, with a recent survey showing wide satisfaction with the lsquovirtualrsquo sea cadetsrsquo programme.Captain Phil Russell, RN, Captain of Sea Cadets, said Chris was one of the ldquoordinary heroes across the UK who was helping Sea Cadets offer a dferent kind of adventure to young people.As officer-in-charge he is holding weekly Zoom sessions and Google Classrooms to train sea cadets in a series of skills such as in first aid, cooking and engineering.Captain Russell said: ldquoSea Cadets are proud of our strong links with the Royal Navy but volunteers join us from all walks of le and no previous nautical experience is needed.ldquoWhen you start volunteering with us you can be assured of a warm welcome and an amazing experience as part of the sea cadet family.Musselburgh Sea Cadets also recently raised funds through crowdfunding to buy treats such as sweets, chocolates and small gts for hard-working frontline health care workers during the Covid- crisis.A major pound, refurbishment of TS Indefatigable, their South Street base, had also just got underway when the Covid- lockdown struck.Potential volunteers who want to join Sea Cadets can find their local unit by going to the website at www.sea-cadets.orgVolunteersrsquo Week takes place June - every year.Itrsquos a chance to celebrate and say thank you for the contribution millions of volunteers make across the UK.

title: animal-loving-teenager-gains-two-qualifications-one-day
story: Chloe English, , successfully completed two accredited assessments in Animal Care lsquoremotelyrsquo and is now hoping to go to college to further her studies.For a long time, she did not feel comfortable at school, as she felt ldquooverwhelmed when she was around people.It was only when she went to to see a counsellor that she discovered her stress was caused by anxiety, which proved a turning point for her.After being diagnosed with anxiety, she was able to be referred for appropriate support and started using the services of both East Lothian Works, the countyrsquos employability and business advice centre, and Musselburgh-based Bridges Project for young people, and has not looked back since.As she is interested in animals, Chloe decided to undertake the Animal Course training programme offered by the Bridges Project.This aims to give young people social skills while increasing their knowledge of animals and obtaining a certicate for their CV.Since starting with Bridges Project in the middle of last year, she has now completed three units of Animal Care.The fact that Chloe completed both the Health and Safety unit and Feeding and Watering unit in one day remotely on her own during lockdown has impressed her tutor, Susan Kerr.Ms Kerr said: ldquoIt is very impressive. This proves that Chloe can manage her workload on her own and keep good routines.ldquoShe has been a joy to work with.Chloe is also very pleased with her achievements and claims that the lockdown actually made it easier for her to work on her assessments.She said: ldquoIt is quite relaxing to study during lockdown.ldquoI have been able to do things at my own pace and it has given me something positive to focus on which can help me move towards my future, she added.In addition to her Animal Care units, the former Ross High School student has also completed a self-evaluation course.Through these courses, she says she has met new friends and been able to talk to people she wouldnrsquot have talked to before.She said: ldquoBridges Project has helped me become more confident, especially when talking in front of other people and when expressing what I want to say.Ms Kerr added: ldquoEast Lothian Works and her counsellor have helped Chloe a lot, and done a great job.East Lothian Works has also organised for Chloe to volunteer in Oxfamrsquos Haddington shop. This has been another good experience which has given the teenager more responsibility and an insight into the retail world.Even though she has been enjoying her volunteering experience, Chloe still hopes that she can continue to work with animals in the future. She already takes care of her dogs, and also has a rabbit.Ms Kerr said: ldquoChloe is absolutely devoted to her rabbit and it must have a lovely time with her. She is very caring and loves animals.The teenager is now hoping to study something related to animals at college in the near future.ldquoI believe I will be nervous going to college but it will be much more enjoyable than it would have been before. I know I can do it now, she added.

title: letter-frustrations-refusal-cats-pyjamas
story: It seems completely bizarre that the roads department would essentially encourage drink driving by decreeing that we require seven parking spaces.Parking standards are determined at a local level with East Lothianrsquos ying from other local authorities but, in the case of East Lothian, bars restaurants require one space per square metre of public space. Hotels require one space per room.I understand that the parking standards have only recently come into effect and all other licensed premises have the benefit of being historical licensed premises and therefore protected. However, I fully believe that a common sense approach should have been taken in this instance, particularly as I submitted a very detailed travel plan which included not only promoting nearby parking options, bus timetables and taxis but actually incentivised travel to and from The Catrsquos Pyjamas by bus, taxi or on foot. When coming up with the concept of The Catrsquos Pyjamas in late summer early autumn  the first thing I did, being a total novice to owning a bar, was to engage with the licensing department.The licensing standards officer advised me I could operate with occasional licences whilst working toward the full premises licence so after submitting the occasional licence applications I was surprised to be told by planning I needed to submit a change of use application for the occasional licences.Bewildered by the conflicting information but just wishing to do what was required, I immediately submitted the application and paid the associated fee.It is frustrating that I was erroneously informed that a change of use was required for occasional licences which stopped me operating and establishing precedent.It is also frustrating I find myself in this situation because I accepted the advice and guidance of East Lothian Council. I am not seeking to apportion all the blame on the council as I have made mistakes, the biggest of which is being naive enough to believe that those who should have and give you the correct information actually do have and give you the correct information. What we have created at The Catrsquos Pyjamas is truly special. Those who have enjoyed an evening with us will validate that.I have had such incredible support from people across Dunbar and beyond that it continues to blow my mind. There is a real desire for The Catrsquos Pyjamas to work and given the chance it could become something truly amazing which is beneficial not only to the town but the county. But this journey has been very painful and costly.There has been a clear campaign against The Catrsquos Pyjamas to the point of it being a vendetta.Objectors have ly contacted the police to report noise when there was none ndash veried by Police Scotland ndash just to get it on the record ahead of the licensing board hearing. I need to take time to reflect on everything that has happened, to reflect on the impact that it has had on myself and my family. I need to investigate whether another location would be better orthe business model should change.At the moment all I can say is sincere thank you to everyone who has supported this venture from the outset and especially to my family for all the blood, sweat, tears and cash they have put into creating this very special place.Ross Hardie,The Catrsquos Pyjamas,Belhaven,Dunbar

title: kids-create-chain-key-workers-tesco-superstore
story: They were asked to create a window display for the store by its community champion, Jane Shepherd, and were rewarded with some treats.The hub, based at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, provides learning and childcare. Those who attend include the children of key workers and others with severe and complex additional support needs.Scarlett Palmer, depute head teacher at Pinkie St Peterrsquos, said: ldquoThe children, along with the staff, in their hub groups decided to create a chain of key workers with a rainbow shining over them.ldquoThe children decided which key workers should be represented and worked in small teams to design and decorate them based on their version of what the unorms should look like.ldquoThey had lots of fun making them and were rewarded with ice pops from Tesco, which were lovely on a warm day.ldquoThe display looks great in Tesco and Irsquom sure is bringing a little joy to customers as they queue outside.

title: dean-jones-raises-2-000-walk-scott-foundation
story: Dean Jones picked up a microphone every day throughout May and performed more than  songs to boost the good cause.The talented singer asked members of the public to make a donation and he would went down really well.ldquoI saw the Walk With Scott Foundation had donated pound, to the East Lothian Foodbank, which was a big outlay.ldquoTheir yearly walk got cancelled, which led to a big depletion of their funds.ldquoThey are a charity I am quite close to and I knew Scott Glynn [founder of the charity who passed away earlier this year] and his son, Gareth.ldquoI came up with the idea Lockdown, which has a million subscribers and people that have been on The Voice and The X-Factor.ldquoWe did a lot of theme streams ndash golden oldies hour, Scottish theme stream, George Ezra v Gerry Cinnamon.It was not just Dean performing to the masses.He was joined on a weekly basis by -year-old daughter Lyla and son Cooper .Their dad added: ldquoWe also did a Star Wars theme on May  where me and the kids dressed up in Star Wars costumes and did lsquoThe Wookiee Sleeps Tonightrsquo as a play on The Lion Sleeps Tonight.But it was not Dean who brought the curtain down and sang the title: schoolchildren-share-self-help-guides-coping-lockdown
story: They were tasked with producing, from home, advice on how to relax, and how to deal with boredom and being at home for such a long time.The youngsters in P also shared fun and interesting activities theyrsquod enjoyed during the lockdown.Teacher Stefan Thomson said: ldquoThis was part of their weekly learning grid, which contains learning tasks from a iety of dferent curricular areas.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded with the resilience pupils have shown during this time.He added: ldquoThis task was intended to be a fun way to share coping strategies among pupils.ldquoHowever, after reading their amazing suggestions I realised how useful these could be for everyone finding it hard to cope.The children suggested activities such as yoga and meditation, as well as stressing the need for healthy eating.

title: community-effort-sees-well-7-000-meals-delivered-residents
story: And such is their prowess, they are now closing in on , meals!The ,th meal was handed over on May  to -year-old Margaret Mack, of Port Setonrsquos Thomson Crescent the servicersquos oldest customer, by the resilience teamrsquos youngest volunteer, Imogen Woods, , who regularly delivers Margaretrsquos meals.During lockdown, staff and volunteers at the Port Seton Centre have been producing and delivering hot meals and food packages to vulnerable residents and those most in need.They have been working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, who have been leading the local resilience effort.The centre is also supporting the work of the local school hub by providing children who would usually receive free school meals with breakfast and lunch packs.Bryan Hickman, chairman of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoI didnrsquot expect us to produce that many.ldquoItrsquos been going on as things continue, and helping a iety of people such as those shielding. . . we donrsquot know how long these people are going to be kept in.Donations of food have come from local residents, groups and businesses, as well as East Lothian Council and FareShare.The FareShare hub was set up last month, and sees surplus food from supermarkets donated to the centre.A new fridge and freezer was also delivered to the centre to store any fresh or frozen food that was delivered. Emma Brown, connected communities manager for the Preston Seton Gosford area, said: ldquoThe Port Seton Centre is delighted to be an active partner in the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, providing vital support to vulnerable people during Covid-.ldquoWe are now far past the , meal delivery ndash and actually closer to , ndash and it shows how working together can make such a dference to community response.ldquoIt has been great to partner the community council, connected communities Preston Seton Gosfordstaff team, childrenrsquos hub, our vital volunteers and other members of the PSG Area Partnership to provide a local response.

title: letter-week-the-worst-time-us-all-many-years
story: It is all rightyou have a garden but,not, being confined to the house may be very nerve-wrackingyou have children to entertain.And what about elderly people who are on their own, what do they do I am alone, I donrsquot have family, so I depend on home care people coming in daily to help me cope from day to day. Unfortunately, I had major heart surgery in November last year and I have been mainly housebound in all that time, and I look forward to be able to get out for a wee while, as being in for thisof time has become very depressing.People are going out and about talking to each other and visiting their relatives but not everyone is following the rules, but people will do what they want.I would love to get out and about but I need someone to take me in a wheelchair but I donrsquot know who or when this will happen.Good luck to everyone.Carol McKayHaddington

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Gford. welcome chance to catch up and support each other, and some are enjoying a break from their duties.Ellie Thomson has continued to create additional face coverings, which are available from Hoggs Newsagent and are made from polycotton and machine washable.Gford Community Council said Ellie has volunteered to create a tutorial for volunteers from the village craft groups, which usually meet in Lanterne Rouge, so they can also share their skills producing coverings.A spokesperson said: ldquoWith the slight relaxation of lockdown rules we have seen family networks begin to be able to reconnect to support one another.ldquoSome of our volunteers are using this opportunity to take a well-earned break from duties, mindful that demand for our services may increase again depending on lockdown arrangements.ldquoSoup And A Smile continues to grow, with universally positive feedback.ldquoOur resilience team continue to meet via phone twice a week to review our activities and plan how we can continue to develop and respond to emerging needs.ldquoFinally, it seems only appropriate that, in Volunteer Week, we take this very public opportunity to thank everyone who is contributing to the Covid response in Gford.ldquoWe are very grateful for your help, support and enthusiasm, as are the people you have been helping.Contact detailsAnyone who needs support or wants to help can contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or The Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddington and DistrictA BREAKDOWN of what volunteers in Haddington have achieved during lockdown has been produced.The community resilience team, Picture: Google MapsMusselburghTWO hundred tubs full of chocolates are being gted to isolating members of the community in the Musselburgh area during the Covid- crisis.The donations of Quality Street, from hospitality company BaxterStorey, were organised by Councillor Andy Forrest and are being distributed, along with kindness cards, by the Resilient Musselburgh volunteers.Staff from East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities, working alongside the Resilient Musselburgh team, identied members of the community who were in isolation or who were on their own and needed a little bit of kindness at this dficult time.Numerous calls of appreciation have been received via the grouprsquos dedicated number monitored by Irene Tait, chairwoman of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council.She said: ldquoCalls were received from members of the community who were overwhelmed by the kind gesture and greatly appreciative of the support we are providing to the community.She added: ldquoThe community support has continued to be fantastic, with recent financial donation from the Eskmuthe Rowing Club.ldquoThe Resilient Musselburgh team are very grateful.ldquoThis week is Volunteer Week  and we wish to thank our contingent of -plus community volunteerswho, from the beginning of this response, have been outstanding in the support of their community every day and continue to be so.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .

story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Aberlady. He said: ldquoWe are not particularly aware of anybody having any particular problems.ldquoWe have got a fair number of volunteers and there are messages being delivered every day.ldquoIt is all small scale stuff.Contact detailsAnyone needing help should contact either Ian Malcolm on   or Sam Robertson on  . Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council chairperson Brian Weddell has appealed to people to stick to the lockdown guidelines, after a weekend which saw people travel from ldquofar and wide to East Lothianrsquos beauty spots.Brian said the community resilience team were working hard to ensure the most vulnerable residents are receiving support and supplies during the lockdown, and the actions of daytrippers over the weekend had left them concerned.He said: ldquoUnfortunately, many peoplersquos worst fears were confirmed over the weekend with East Lothian being inundated with daytrippers driving down the coast from far and wide.ldquoDespite the very clear messages being given last week by the Scottish Government and East Lothian Council that the lsquorelaxed lockdown measuresrsquo still included only travellingessential, staying home as much as possible, not travelling more than five miles from your local area, avoiding tourist and beauty spots ndash the East Lothian coast road was rammed with cars all weekend and the beaches packed.As one local Panner put it to me: lsquoFolk are just going mental and not listening to what the governments are saying.rsquoldquoThe last thing we all need after more than two months of strict lockdown measures is a second wave of infections that puts huge pressure on the NHS and frontline health and social care services, as well as the resilience volunteers.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos lsquotesting and tracingrsquo strategy is now operational and people need to listen to the advicethey are asked to self-isolate."It is in their own interests and those of their family, friends and neighbours to stick to the rules.Last week was the busiest yet for the Pennypit Pantry, with , meals delivered over the course of the week.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, highlighted in last weekrsquos Courier, delivered  meals over the weekend.The community council also gave special thanks to Calum story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirIT IS BUSINESS as usual for the resilience team in Macmerry and Gladsmuir, and those who need help of any kind are encouraged to reach out and get in touch.Last month, the group started a pom pom initiative, which has been going from strength to strength over the weeks.It has seen both Macmerry and Gladsmuir decorated with pom poms hung by residents from places such as trees and fences using ribbons placed by resilience volunteers.The initiative has not only brightened up both villages but has also worked as a way to thank all key workers who continue to work amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Stevie Sutherland, one of the co-ordinators, told the Courier that a banner was to be put up outside Macmerry Miners Club, also thanking key workers.The resilience teamrsquos hot meals service continues, and volunteers are still helping with shopping, prescription uplts and post office visits.Work on how community support can continue now restrictions have started to ease also continues, with efforts being made to ensure the system can pick up and run again without any issues.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can find out more information at twitter MacmerryTeamOrmiston. Picture: Google MapsOrmistonRESIDENTS in Ormiston have been given a boost after the gala committee announced it will hold its annual Best Dressed House competition this month.Gala days across the county have been affected by the lockdown, with many, like Ormistonrsquos, cancelled.However, the committee is inviting people to enter their houses in the competition ahead of the socially distant judging, which is due to take place on June .Anyone can put forward their home and the deadline for taking part is June .The gala committee is also appealing for other ideas for activities that could be held within the current guidelines for social distancing.Friends of Ormiston Park have also reminded people that, while the easing of restrictions means people can meet in parks at a safe distance, childrenrsquos play areas remain closed.Contact detailsVolunteers are continuing to provide support and services to the most vulnerable residents and anyone in need can get in touch by contacting them on   between am and pm, seven days a week, or emailing Ormistonrcrteam@hotmailTranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTHE resilience effort in Tranent continues to support local residents, and further appeals have been launched for volunteers and those who have been helping neighbours.Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council has been overseeing the local resilience effort, led by member Mike Falconer, the grouprsquos single point of contact .Mike has asked that residents who have been supporting their neighbours during the pandemic ndash for example, by helping with shopping ndash and who will soon be ing to work, potentially leaving neighbours without support, get in touch with him.People requesting the resilience teamrsquos help for neighbours have been asked to get their neighboursrsquo permission before calling.A second appeal has been put out for volunteers to support the grouprsquos food delivery service, which operates from St Martinrsquos Church Hall.Mike said: ldquoWe desperately need help from volunteers to direct the delivery driver volunteers coming in and out of the St Martinrsquos Church Hall car park Blair Halls food delivery base to the correct venue ndash especially when staff and some pupils start toto the school building.ldquoThis would involve being at St Martinrsquos Church Hall car park from approximately .am until about pm, Monday to Saturday ndash but not necessarily every day,you canrsquot manage.ldquoThe volunteers have delivered thousands of meals over the last few weeks and months but we need your help to keep it running smoothly.Contact detailsAnyone interested in either appeal is asked to contact Mike on tranentemergencyresponse@gmail or call  .

The First Minister said the Government has not made a final decision whether to implement the policy.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media AlflgpM poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests AlflgpM.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:What are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:The one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.Heres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: column-easing-lockdown-restrictions-ruined-stupidity-others-says-msp
story: LAST weekend was the first of lsquophase onersquo of easing the lockdown, which now seems to have been with us forever.Many of us took the chance to see family face to face, albeit outside and at a distance, for the first time in many weeks.Others were able to enjoy golf, bowls or fishing at long last, eventhe clubhouse remained off limits.What a pity that some communities had any joy they might have felt in some easing of restrictions ruined by the stupidity of others who abused that progress.The countyrsquos coastal villages and other beauty spots were swamped with people heading for a day out and simply ignoring the advice not to travel more than five miles for leisure.Finding car parks and toilets closed, they parked, peed and worse without consideration, then left litter everywhere.The council has been caught between a rock and a hard place, instructed by the First Minister not to open car parks, andthey do facing accusations of encouraging the flouting of the rules. Yet chaos resulted.I know the council is discussing with government and COSLA how to respond. Police, traffic wardens and Countryside Rangers did their best but were overwhelmed.On Monday, the First Minister made clear thatthis continues we will go back into lockdown, and the guidance will be given the force of law but perhaps we should have done that first, and hopefully as we move into other phases the guidance will be better thought out, clearer and unambiguous.A further sign that we are not yet out of the woods was an inexplicable fall in numbers of Covid- tests.Further phases of leaving lockdown, such as school openings, depend on widespread community testing, and in parliament we continue to get no answers on why this is still not happening.There is still a real danger that the infection rate will rise again and more people will die unnecessarily.We all have a part to play. Please do follow the guidance to save lives.

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: tim-tales-kings-elephant
story: This week is a story from India which I like, not least because the main character is my favourite animal an elephant.Irsquove loved elephants since early childhood. They are a giant of nature, yet also incredibly intelligent. They feel emotion like we do, in fact possibly more so as the emotional part of their brain is even more developed than that of humans.The old saying that ldquoan elephant never forgets is rooted in this fact. An elephantrsquos emotional intelligence comes from its ability to remember and recall distant memory. Like humans, an elephantrsquos way of being is mostly learned in early le, rather than just based on instinct.They are therefore highly sensitive creatures, influenced and affected by what they experience just as we are.Irsquove heard dferent versions of this tale, and here I have peppered it very slightly with my own style:Once, a king in ancient India owned an elephant. This royal elephant was the joy not just of the king, but also his people.The trainer would ride the elephant every day along the streets. She was a magnicent sight, and children would run out to wave and watch the elephant go by. The trainer took a dferent route each day so people in dferent neighbourhoods all had a chance to enjoy the spectacle.The people felt a real love and affinity for the elephant. Despite her size and strength, she was gentle and affectionate with the people. She would pat children carefully on their heads with her trunk and took care in where she walked.The elephant made people feel safe. More than once she had saved a child from drowning in the nearby river, or from a predator from the jungle. She was a sacred animal to the people.But then people began to notice a change in the elephantrsquos behaviour. She became aggressive and unpredictable. Instead of being patient with the children she knocked them out of her way with her trunk. Instead of being careful where she walked, she deliberately trampled on peoplersquos gardens.The trainer tried his best to control the elephant, but she seemed like a dferent animal. He couldnrsquot understand why she was behaving so dferently.It just got worse, until one day the elephant suddenly set off on a charge and rampaged through the streets, trumpeting loudly as she charged at the terried people, almost killing some of them.The king was horried and ordered the elephant to be confined to her stables. With dficulty she was finally brought under control and locked in.ldquoWhat is going on  asked the king to the trainer.ldquoI have no idea your majesty he replied, ldquoitrsquos asshe is a dferent elephant.ldquoPerhaps the elephant is ill in some way  suggested one of the kingrsquos advisors. But the vet found nothing physically wrong.Then the trainer suggested asking an old man who lived in the jungle as ldquohe is known for his wisdom in understanding animals, perhaps he will know what the cause of this is.So the king sent a messenger and the old man came to the royal palace.ldquoCan you help  asked the king.The old man asked to be left alone with the elephant for a while.When he ed he looked at the king and said: ldquoWhatever is wrong is something that cannot be seen. I must spend some time with the elephant to understand what is troubling her.And so the old man decided to watch over the elephant that night. He smeared himself in mud to mask his scent and hid in a corner of the stable.It was late evening when he heard voices.A group of men had entered the stables from a small side door. They were a gang of murderers. They were using the royal elephant stable as a place to meet and plan their activities. And in so doing they recounted stories of their deeds.Their leader was a man with a cold and ruthless heart. He told stories about his le and deeds, of how hersquod murdered and tortured people he didnrsquot like. Members of his gang laughed and shared their tales too, likewise full of hatred and cruelty.The elephant slumbered as these tales were told, but they were unknowingly heard by her. When the elephant woke the following morning, the tales of hate and violence still swirled in her mind.The old man went to the king.ldquoYour majesty, there are two things you must do to cure the elephant.ldquoThe first is to remove the murderers who meet in the stables at night. The second is you must find the kindest people, who live their lives with love and understanding. Then ask them to meet at night in the stable as the elephant sleeps and tell each other stories from their lives tales of love and understanding. If you do this, then the elephant will be cured.The king looked bemused.ldquoI will most certainly remove the murderers, he said, ldquobut are you saying that stories will cure the elephant ldquoYes, your majesty, replied the old man, ldquobut the right stories. You see we are made from the stories we hear.He went on: ldquoIf we constantly hear tales of hatred and violence then those stories paint our vision of le with fear, loathing and cruelty.ldquoButwe mostly hear tales of love and understanding, then our mind is coloured with kindness for others, and for ourselves.ldquoWe are affected by the stories we hear, evenwe donrsquot realise we have been listening to them.ldquoYour elephant was unknowingly listening to tales of hatred and killing every night as she slept. So her mind was filled with hate and distrust her vision of the world changed and so did her behaviour.ldquoIf she hears good stories then she will eventually become her kind self again.The king nodded in understanding and agreed to act on this. Within a few weeks the elephantrsquos behaviour had changed for the better.ldquoYou are indeed wise in the ways of elephants, the king said to the old man.ldquoThe truth in this is not just for elephants, the old man replied.ldquoPeople are like your elephant the stories they hear will paint their world and affect how they live in it.The king nodded once again.ldquoMy job is done, said the old man, ldquoI will nowto the forest.ldquoBy the way, your elephant will have a calf, and her calf must hear good stories too.ldquoHow can I pay you for your wisdom  asked the king.The old man thought for a moment, then said: ldquoBe a king who tells good stories tales of kindness and understanding. And be a good listener to the stories told by your people.ldquoThen you will be a truly great leader and your kingdom will flourish and be a happier place.ldquoIf you do that, it will be my greatest reward.

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST tonight .According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three orfour days.

title: black-lives-matter-donate-help-get-diverse-books-primary-schools
story: The fund -which has raised over pound, since it was created on Wednesday, June  - aims to help black, Asian and minority ethnicstudents to feel represented by their school libraries.The initiative was inspired by protests that have taken place across the world calling for justice after the death of George Floyd, who died in police custody in Minneapolis on May .Who created the fund Scott Emmons, who created the fund, told the PA news agency:ldquoTherersquos a lack of books in primary schools where not only can teachers teach the white students about these issues, but also the BAME students are severely under-represented in the books that they have."Mr Emmons, , who lives in Wanstead, added: ldquoI went to the protest on Wednesday in Hyde Park and came away feeling so energised. There were so many people in Hyde Park who caredhellip there are so many people wanting to change, wanting to help.What books will the fund help The fund will put bundles into libraries, which include  books for children aged three to , and include the stories of Nelson Mandela and Rosa Parks.In , a report from the Centre for Literacy in Primary Education revealed that over the course of the year, only  per centof childrenrsquos books published in the UK had a BAME hero.These books allow those dficult conversations to startldquoIf therersquos no literature there to start this conversation, and white teachers find it dficult to speak about, then these are the tools that allow you to have that conversation, Mr Emmons told PA.Mr Emmons explained that he would like the initiative to go further than the GoFundMe page he has created, with the hope of schools tailoring the books to fit their own schoolsrsquo needs.He said: ldquoThe idea for this campaign is not to pay for everyonersquos books, itrsquos to be that driving force and that spark to put pressure on schools to get these books in and allow the children in their classrooms to see themselves represented.ldquoIt isnrsquot just a case of a lack of fundinghellip a lot of the schools do have the funding theyrsquore just not prioritising correctly. Theyrsquore not purchasing the right books.How can I make a donation To see the pagersquos donations, visit: http:gofundme f help-our-children-read-about-race

title: tell-difference-symptoms-hay-fever-covid-19
story: It comes as the weather gets warmer and summer approaches, with hay fever sufferers having to cope with more pollen in the air.But could coughing be a sign of hayfever, and as coronavirus sticks around, how can you tell it apart from allergy symptoms Heres what you need to know.What is hay fever Hay fever, also known as seasonal allergies, tends to flare up between late March and September according to the NHS, as this is when itrsquos warm, humid, windy and when pollen count is at its highest.Healthline says: ldquoWhen your body is exposed to allergens, it releases histamines.ldquoHistamines are meant to protect you from harm, but they can also cause the allergy symptoms that make some seasons uncomfortable.Hay fever and its symptoms are not contagious for those around you.Is coughing a symptom of hay fever Hay fever comes with a lot of dferent symptoms, one of which is a cough.Other symptoms include:The NHS says thatyou also suffer from asthma, you might also experience:How do I tell the dference between hay fever and coronavirus With hay fever and coronavirus having overlapping symptoms, like coughing, loss of smell and headaches, some people might get confused about what their symptoms mean.Most hay fever sufferers are affected from childhood, and will probably be expecting their symptoms every year around the same time.If yoursquove never had hay fever before, and you suddenly begin experiencing symptoms, itrsquos understandable that this might cause concern.Patient Info says: ldquoAround one in five people with hay fever get symptoms for the first time over the age of , so therersquos no reason to assume an adultrsquos symptoms canrsquot be caused by hayfever just because theyrsquove never had it before.Marc Donovan, chief pharmacist at Boots, says: ldquoHay fever doesnrsquot cause a high temperature and most people donrsquot feel unwell.The NHS explains that the two main symptoms of Covid- are a high temperature and a new, continuous cough.A high temperature means that you feel hot to touch on your chest or back - you do not need to measure your temperature.A new, continuous cough is also defined as ldquocoughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours.Boots Pharmacy released an graphic which shows the dference between hay fever symptoms and coronavirus symptoms, and included information like:How do I treat hay fever There is currently no cure for hayfever, but there are things you can do to help your symptoms according to the NHS, which includes:A pharmacy can also help with hay fever as they can provide you with things like antihistamine tablets or nasal sprays to help with your symptoms.

title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: The First Minister saidthat, "at least in part", more of the coronavirus lockdown measures will be eased on at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that, ten days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhile not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygeine measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants CAN open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - so long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab andresearch facilities.The contruction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNz pic tjtWu
