title: black-lives-matter-every-scottish-street-linked-slave-trade-revealed
story: Black Lives Matter protests across the globe have thrust our nationrsquos history into the spotlight once again ndash with thousands taking to the our streets and parks joining calls from around the world for racial equality.The catalyst for the growing unrest: the death of -year-old black man George Floyd in Minnesota, when a white police officer knelt on his neck for more than eight minutes.And with support growing for the renaming of streets in Scotland linked to the slave-trade, research from the University College Londonhas revealed the true extent of Scotlandrsquos dark ties.The death of George Floyd has sparked mass protestsAcross the country, more than  addresses that benefited from the money in the slave-trade have been identied.Edinburgh proved to be a major benefactor in the list ndash with more than  addresses highlighted.In Glasgow, just under  places were noted in the list, with  in both Ayrshire and the Borders.There were  cases in Fe, with a further  in Stirling and  in Inverclyde, West Dunbartonshire and Argyll and Bute.BLM protests took place across Scotland over the weekendAcross the UK, there are  addresses listed on the map.As the researchers from the UCLs Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave-ownership note: "Each address pinpoints a slave-owner or direct beneficiary in a particular place at a specic time."You can view the interactive map HEREwith all the locations listed by the UCL.You can find out more information about the address and occupiers past by clicking on the blue markers.Follow the link above to view the interactive map

title: mcdonalds-glasgow-set-open-walk-ins-month---
story: Following a closed test in London last month,  service station locations on UK motorways will open for takeaway from next Wednesday.Then, from June  onwards, they will gradually roll-out to high streets, towns and city centres.The fast-food chain also plan a trialled relaunch of the McDonaldrsquos breakfast service from that date.There is currently one McDonalds restaurant in East Lothian, in Dunbar on Spott Road beside the towns Asda store.McDonaldrsquos UK  Ireland CEO Paul Pomroy said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be back.ldquoI am extremely proud of our employees, franchisees and suppliers who are working so hard in so many communities already.ldquoThe high street is at the heart of our business, it is where we started in the UK, in Woolwich over  years ago.ldquoIn line with Government changes to lockdown restrictions, over the next few weeks and months wersquoll reopen on high streets across the UK and in towns and cities in Ireland.ldquoI know that opening those doors will be incredibly satisfying for our restaurant teams, but it will also mean them getting used to the measures we have implemented to enable us to safely .ldquoSo please continue to support them and follow the social distancing measures wersquove introduced for the safety of our teams and you.What do McDonaldrsquos say about new safety measures -We will provide clear signposting and floor-markings to create a one-way system around our restaurants for you and our delivery partner couriers-We will only allow certain numbers of people inside our restaurants at a time to help you and us adhere to social distancing ndash this will y depending upon the restaurant size and lay-out-When you visit us for takeaway, we will welcome you inside when a space becomes available, and wersquoll ask you to sanitise your hands at the cleaning stations we are introducing in all restaurants-We will have fewer self-order screens switched on and will sanitise those in use at least every  minutes. You can also order via the My McDonaldrsquos app-If you can visit alone to collect your food, please do so, however we know this isnrsquot always possible ndash children are of course still welcome, but for now wersquoll be putting away our crayons and colouring sheets and keeping the play areas and digital play areas closed-Our seating areas, customer toilets and lts will remain closed-As our dining areas will not be open, our recycling points will also remain closed but most of our packaging can be recycled so please do dispose of it responsibly and recycle wherever possible when you get home-To help protect our employees and other customers, we ask you not to visityou feel unwell.

title: dentists-plan-reopen-glasgow-practices-open-doors-england
story: Currently all practices are closed apart from telephone triage, with increased care offered at emergency dental hubs and urgent dental care centres.Scotlandrsquos Chief Dental Officer Tom Ferris detailed out the plans in a letter published yesterday as he updated the progress of the lsquoremobilisation of NHS Dental Services in Scotlandrsquo as we move our way out of the coronavirus lockdown.He writes that as part of the plans, the Scottish Government hopes to reintroduce services ldquoon a phased basis over the course of this month.The precise date will be confirmed at the next -weekly review of lockdown regulations, which takes place on June  ndash with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon already confirming she is ldquooptimistic the country will move into Phase  of the route map out of lockdown on that date.So, what does this mean If Scotland does indeed move into Phase  from June , then all dental practices would be permitted to open to see patients with ldquourgent care needs from this point ndash provided they are non-aerosol generating procedures.Mr Ferris however notes that ldquonot all dental practices will be able to open at the same time as some practices may take longer to prepare.He continued: ldquoThe start date is not to be considered a target ndash practices must be certain they can safely open before they do.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNz pic NojpLpSdcWhat about Phase  and From Phase , which is a currently  date but could be as soon as mid-July, all dental practices can reopen to see registered patients, even without ldquourgent needs.And from Phase , there will be a limited introduction of aerosol generating proceduresto dental practices, which will be dependent on evidence of risk and possible mitigation.How does this compare to England #Dental practices in England were permitted to reopen yesterday for the first time since lockdown rules were introduced.There, the British Dental Associationhas told practices to prioritise patients with urgent need and vulnerable groups when resuming services, with an increase in demand expected to work through the backlog.But not all dentists down south were happy with the decision ndash in a warning that could be a sign of things to come in Scotland.They want the UK Government to provide further support, saying so far it has been ldquotoo limited.One dentist has described theto work as ldquonerve-wracking.The BDA union has asked for dentists to be granted key worker status and access to the Government supply chain on PPE, as one industry survey suggests only around one third of surgeries in England, %, opened yesterday.

title: new-musselburgh-racecourse-operators-hope-take-return-racing-month
story: The racecourse hopes to see aof racing, behind closed doors, at the end of the month with back to back fixtures proposed on June  and July .And at a online video call meeting on Tuesday of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , which oversees the racecourse, it was revealed new operator Chester Racing Company hopes to be in place before the first date.East Lothian Councils legal adviser Carlo Grilli said negotiations over the takeover were ongoing but it was hoped Chester would be in place later this month.He said: "Given the end of June has a potential fixture the proposal for Chester would be to take over a few days prior to the end of June to get a few days prior in."East Lothian Council has been negotiating with Chester after it was named the preferred bidders for a contract to operate the course last year.The course, which sits on common good land, had previously been run by a governance committee made up of elected councillors and representatives of Lothians Racing Syndicate ndash originally Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee and more recently MRAC.The decision to bring in a third party operator came after the British Horseracing Authority threatened to remove Musselburghrsquos racing licence when relations between the members of the previous committee became toxic one-month extensions were put in place to allow the new operator to come in.Last month the BHA extended the licence until the end of October.Councillor Fiona ODonnell, MRAC chairperson, said she and fellow members had held talks with Chester over their involvement in the town in the future.She said: "It says a lot about Musselburgh that they are still very keen. Chester have some really positive intentions in terms of the local community as well and this is good news."Councillor Stuart Currie, MRAC member, welcomed news Chester was still keen to take over, pointing out the council could have been back to "square one"they had taken a step back during the Covid- crisis.He said: "That Chester is still taking over the running of the race course is really positive. It could have been the case that some people might have turned around and said they did not want to do anything right now and we would have been back at square one."It is important for the racing industry and it is important for the staff at Musselburgh."The committee which met via Skype chose to hear a health and safety report and report by the racecourse general manager in private citing commercial reasons for not discussing them in public.

title: small-car-parks-reopen-locals
story: Most of the local authoritys coastal car parks remain closed as it tries to deter daytrippers from heading to East Lothian.However, smaller rural car parks and a few of the more remote coastal car parks have been reopened.The local authoritydecided to reopen some of the facilities quietly and "without fanfare" as it aimed to keep visitors local.Public toilets and childrenrsquos play areas remain closed and Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesman, appealed to people to stay within their local areas.He said:ldquoIn line with Scottish Government guidance, we have decided to proceed with a partial re-opening of car parks ndash focused on smaller coastal and inland countryside parking sites."This will provide local residents, particularly those who are less mobile and may have dficulty accessing the countryside by foot or bike, with more access to the coast or countryside for leisure and exercise.ldquoWe do understand why people from other areas wanted to visit our beautul coast and beaches during the recent spell of warm weather. But progress in tackling Covid- remains fragile."Therefore, given the need to reduce the risk of popular beauty spots becoming crowded and potentially unsafe, our larger coastal car parks will remain closed at this time.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors from further afield to these sites and where in East Lothian when it is safe to do so but at the moment we would ask that people do not travel to beauty spots from out with their local area."Car parks now open for local residents at coastal sites are:Back Sands and Mountjoy, Fisherrow, MusselburghLevenhall Links, MusselburghMorrisonrsquos Haven, Prestongrange, and Prestongrange Mining MuseumPreston Links Sailing Club, PrestonpansPond Hall, on The Promenade, Port Seton North Berwick East BeachLinkfield, John Muir Country Park Shore Road, West BarnsWhite SandsBarns NessSkaterawThorntonloch.Inland car parks now open are:Butterdean, near GladsmuirWoodhall, near PencaitlandTraprain LawPencraig, both near East LintonHopetoun , north of Haddington andPencaitland Railway Walk.

title: east-lothian-mp-quizzes-prime-minister-food-standards
story: Mr MacAskill quizzed Boris Johnston during a virtual Prime Ministers Questions over what would be done to protect current animal welfare and food standards.And he accused the UK Government of failing to "enshrine protections in the agriculture bill".Referring to another of the ongoing debates around a future trade deal with the USA, Mr MacAskill asked the Prime Minister to make an assurance ldquothat we wonrsquot face chlorinated chicken on our table, along with Kentucky-fried medicine in our hospitals.Mr MacAskill called on the Prime Minister to be clear that high standards must be protected and to establish a commission to look at food standards.He said: "I have had a number of constituents contacting me recently to express signicant concerns about the UK Governmentrsquos trade policy." It is clear that food standards, animal welfare, and environmental concerns are not a priority for this government who seem to be more interested in getting any trade deal done to prove a point about Brexit, rather than for the benefit of the people of these islands."The long-awaited Brexit benefits are receding further into the distance every week and the future under an American Trade deal looks grim indeed for the sector and citizens.Last month Minette Batters, the president of the National Farmerrsquos Union ,said: ldquoOur trade policy must reflect our moral responsibilities to the planet and the people and creatures that live on it ndash protecting our natural environment, caring for our farmed animals, and working toward a more sustainable, climate-friendly way of farming and food production. These are issues that cannot be wished away or presumed dealt with by brief pledges in a manesto or verbal assurances in media interviews.Mr Johnson responded to Mr MacAskills question,saying ldquoon leaving the EU, as we have, we will be able to increase our animal welfare standards.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown
story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. title: five-alternative-fathers-day-experiences-lockdown
story: A day trip, family get together, a meal at dads favourite might have been on the cards to celebrate Fathers Day, but with our choices restricted this year due to lockdown there are some great alternatives out there.Your dad might be just as happy, or long for, playing a solitary round of golf at his local course or sitting by the riverbank waiting for his catch of the day, but might also want to come together with loved ones to celebrate his special day.From small garden gatherings, to Zoom parties, or virtual museum tours or a local stroll, we bring you the best ideas to make it a Fathers Day to remember.Virtual Museum TourWhile all their museums remain closed due to coronavirus, the National Museum of Scotland have opened their virtual doors for people to enter a world of discovery.Their website gives you the chance to explore their collections and discover more about amazing objects through stories, films, games and resources.There is the chance to delve into our animated adventures and find out more about le in ancient Egypt, learn some Mandarin. Watch videos on a day in the le of an ancient Egyptian priestPriests occupied a unique place in ancient Egyptian society. Find out what they did every day and why in this short animated film. Created for the Discovering Ancient Egypt gallery.There is also the chance to The East Asian CalendarThe East Asian calendar uses a unique system to measure and mark the passing of time. Discover the twelve animals in the calendar and find out what your animal sign is. Created for the East Asia gallery.For more information go to www.nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-scotland If you fancy going a little further afield in your virtual discovery why not take a look at the Louvre in Paris.Activities on offer at the online Louvre include:- One minute in a museum- YouTubers at the Louvre- Mona Lisa VR experience-  years of history- A closer look at Louvre artworksOr you can take a virtual tour of Founding Myths: From Hercules to Darth Vader.The Louvrersquos Petite Galerie first exhibition tells how illustrators, sculptors, painters, puppeteers, filmmakers, and musicians around the world have drawn inspiration from myths, given them form, and brought them to le.Local family walkNow we are allowed to exercise more than once a day and can meet up with another household, a walk near your home could be the ideal gathering.Check out the Ramblers Scotland website to find walks close to home of dfering levels. A great way to enjoy daily local exercise is to try one of their  free mapped Medal Routes short, circular walks in every local authority area in Scotland.Medal Routes are downloadable maps for short, fun circular walks of ,  or  minutes. They are available in every local authority area across Scotland and there are over  walking routes to choose from.The organisation has been working hard to help inspire people to keep active during lockdown - including via through their #RoamSweetHome campaign.If you are giving the Medal Routes a go in your local area during your daily exercise, they are looking for you to share photos or videos from your Medal Route walk by using the #RoamSweetHome hashtag or tagging us on social media.For more information got to www.ramblers.org.uk scotland.aspxGo for a bike rideSales of bikes have soared during lockdown with many shops now having waiting lists after being completely sold out. Transport Secretary Michael Matheson recently confirmed cycling levels are % higher compared with the lockdown baseline, while Cycling Scotlandrsquos automatic cycling counters at  spots around the country revealed remarkable results, with one in Dunfermline recording an increase of % since lockdown.There are a number of family routes to explore without going too far from home. National Cycle Network routes in Scotland run through many areas of outstanding natural beauty, taking in vast forests, iconic castles, shimmering lochs, tranquil glens and spectacular coastlines. The routes provide a unique snapshot of the countryrsquos rich history whilst also connecting all of Scotlands major cities.There are approximately , milesof National Cycle Network routes in Scotland, including  miles of traffic-free routes which use a mix of railway path, canal towpath, forest road, shared-use path, segregated cycle lanes and redetermined rural footways.More information can be found at www.sustrans.org.ukVirtual park discoveryWhile travelling too far afield might just be a distant dream at the moment, we will have to make do with exploring some parts of the great outdoors from our armchairs.Prepare to feel slightly dizzy on the virtual tour for Calornias Yosemite National Park. Virtual Yosemite is a groundbreaking interactive tour of one of Americarsquos most popular and spectacular natural environments. The project is unique in both the depth of its coverage and the quality of its imagery.It was created and photographed by pioneering virtual realityphotographer Scott Highton, who has specialized in VR photography since the early s.Virtual Yosemite allows online visitors to experience over  dferent locations within Yosemite and its surrounding areas, in all seasons. Over  percent of the locations covered are accessible to Yosemite visitors via roads or trails. The deg interactive panoramas are all presented in high resolution, so viewers can zoom in and out to see details, and can pan fully around, including looking upward and downward. Dizzying views from the tops of Yosemitersquos famous clfs and waterfalls are available, along with peaceful locations along trails and in well-known parts of Yosemite Valley.For more information go to www.virtualyosemite.org Closer to home enjoy an aerial view of Loch Lomond National Park under #Lochdown. See the beauty of nature during the coronavirus lochdown through a series of videos which have been posted on their website. Take in the enchanting Loch Achray, a small freshwater loch in the heart of the Trossachs.For more information go to https:www.lochlomond-trossachs.org park-authority lochdown aerial-tours-of-the-national-park Watch a dads favourite movieYou can now watch some streaming services together evenyou are not in the same household and it could be the answer to having a family movie night while social distancing or apart from dad this Fathers Day.Netflix is one example where you can watch the same film together. Netflix Party is a Google Chrome-exclusive extension that only requires one person to install it, making it easy to set up.Once you install it, choose a movie or show, pause it, and then click the red ldquoNP button at the top right of your browser to get a link to a shared session. The extension allows you to chat with everyone in the viewing session, but doesnrsquot allow you to put in a name, so yoursquoll have to remember your friendsrsquo random symbols.Netflix Party allows for full-screen viewing and anybody in the session can hit pause, play or scrub through the timeline.

title: coronavirus-social-distancing-ferry-restrictions-completely-unsustainable-island-life
story: CalMac Ferries Limited has raised concerns with MSPs that when it is safe to relax restrictions and begin to re-open the tourism sector, stating that it could double the number of passengers it can carrythe two-metre social distancing rule is reduced to just one metre.The company added that ldquoimplementing physical distancing of two metres throughout our operations will reduce the capacity of our fleet on average to  per cent of normal passenger capacity.:CalMac Ferries warns it wont be able to cope with staycation surge amid social distancingNow, Iain Jurgensen chairman of the Argyll  The Isles Tourism Cooperative, has penned a letter to his local MSP Mike Russell and Rural Economy and Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing, raising concerns about the ldquorapidly escalating situation.Mr Ewing is due to give a statement to MSPs today about the impact of Covid- on tourism.Mr Jurgensen has warned that ldquothe massive issues now facing our island communities due to social distancing rules ldquoin effect wipes out any tourism season for  on each island and leave tourism businesses with no realistic source of income and ability to operate, employ local people and sustain local supply chains.He said: ldquoConsistency in actions across the country has been the core government message and yet with these restrictions on ferry travel, islanders themselves cannot enjoy the freedoms that mainlanders have to visit mainland family and friends and in business to know they can open their doors soon and attempt to earn a living.ldquoThe suggested restrictions are completely unsustainable for island le and business resilience. These restrictions are severe and place Scotlandrsquos island communities and tourism enterprises out of kilter with the rest of the country.:Scottish tourism at risk of total collapseldquoIt will not be financially viable to open most tourism businesses with no tourism customer base and we have ready examples to share of businesses that will be forced to make island staff redundant and that will collapse or go into administration and not survive this pandemic.ldquoMany of these businesses are not just for tourists ndash they play a key part in the le and health of locals year-round, are community hubs and support other businesses through local supply chains. The tourism income makes them viable, and without it they will struggle to survive as business entities - with all the serious socio-economic implications this will bring for the inidual island economies."He added: ldquoMany of these businesses have fallen through the cracks in support being made available to date. They are fearful that they will get further into debt and collapse. We cannot overstress the anxiety being experienced as a consequence of these new circumstances.ldquoThe islands are being penalised and we believe unnecessarily. We accept the restrictions reflect social distancing requirements but travel on rail and plane seem to be out of kilter with what is being imposed on ferries. What can be done to make this fair across Scotland :Nicola Sturgeon: Relaxing two-metre rule would likely need stricter face covering guidanceAt her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon stressed that there was no scientic evidence to suggest that the two-metre rule can be relaxed.She added: ldquoI understand the challenges that all businesses are going to face in adapting to the Covid world that we are going to be living in for some time.ldquoTo become operational while not allowing the virus to spread is not going to be easy and we are talking to businesses across all sectors of the economy as we work to put guidance in place for how they do that ndash clearly, thatrsquos going to be more dficult in some sectors than it will be in others.ldquoI have had no advice given to me and to the best of my knowledge, although I obviously donrsquot see all the advice that the UK Government gets, Irsquove not seen anything they have had that would advise a change in the two-metre rule right now. On the contrary, most of the advice I see says the two-metre rules should be retained.

title: coronavirus-spreading-scotland-february-according-new-genetic-research
story: The findings also appear to overturn theories that a Nike sports conference in Edinburgh at the end of February was Scotlandrsquos lsquoGround Zerorsquo for the infection.Dr Gregor Smith, Scotlandrsquos interim chief medical officer, said it was unclear exactly when the virus first arrived in Scotland, but that ldquosome form of community transmission was underway in Scotland probably during the month of February.He added that the same research indicated that infection control measures had been successful in wiping out any cases linked to the Nike conference by the end of March.: Fth of hip fracture patients caught Covid in hospitalThe first known case of Covid- in Scotland was reported on March , in a patient in Tayside who had recently ed from a trip to northern Italy - at the time a Covid hotspot.Sustained community transmission - meaning the infection is being passed widely from person to person within Scotland, without any links to foreign travel - was not confirmed until March .However, scientists have now dated the outbreak to weeks earlier using genomic sequencing.The technique enables them to unpick subtle, but distinctive, molecular signatures in order to identy dferent versions - or lsquolineagesrsquo - of the virus circulating in Scotland.They can then track where each inidual lineage is occurring and how fast it is spreading.Dr Smith said this has ldquoallowed them to identy at least  separate introductions of Covid- to Scotland that ultimately led to sustained community transmission.Within this, they have been able to pick out viral lineages ldquowith no clear link to travel at the very early stages of the outbreak in Scotland, said Dr Smith.He said: ldquoWhat this work tells us is that right back at the start, when we first started experiencing cases in Scotland in the early part of March, although the majority of these cases we were detecting - when you do the genomic sequencing - you could associate them with importations from abroad, not all of them could you clearly determine that there was a travel history.ldquoWhat that suggests is that there was some form of community transmission that was underway in Scotland probably during the month of February.ldquoBut itrsquos dficult to say with any certainty at exactly what point these viruses have been introduced.He stressed that this did not necessarily mean that anyone experiencing Covid-like symptoms in February would have been infected due to high levels of flu and other viral pathogens in the environment at the end of winter.:  people affected by Covid outbreaks in hospitalEven now, nearly  per cent of people with symptoms who are tested for the SARS-CoV- virus prove negative - although up to a third can be  negatives.Mr Smith said: ldquoWe wonrsquot be able to say with certaintysomeone who was experiencing the kinds of symptoms we would associate with Covid  - the cough, the fever - was specically associated with Covid .ldquoAt the moment, the best estimates we have from this genome sequencing is that there were probably importations in February, but we canrsquot say with any certainty other than that when they would have arrived in Scotland.The first known cases of coronavirus in the UK were confirmed on January , in Chinese tourists visiting York.A Nike conference held at the Hilton Carlton Hotel in Edinburgh on February  and  attracted  delegates from around the world.Of the attendees,  were later diagnosed with Covid-, including eight in Scotland.The Scottish Government has come under fire for not publicising the outbreak earlier. It only came to light following a BBC investigation last month.Dr Smith said genetic analysis had linked a further three possible cases to the conference, but two have now been discounted while the third ldquoshows similarities with those associated with the conference, but no direct or indirect link to the conference has been established.He added: ldquoAll show similarities with a viral lineage found in continental Europe.ldquoHowever, this particular sub-lineage has not been detected in Scotland since the end of March.ldquoThis suggests that the actions taken by the [infection management team] were successful in curtailing spread and have led to the eradication of this particular viral lineage, with no evidence of any wider outbreak associated with it in Scotland since that time.: Edinburgh doctors see big drop in broken bones from assualts and road collisions since start of CovidIt comes as a study from Hard Medical School suggested that the new virus could have emerged in Wuhan, China as far back as September or October last year, based on a ldquodramatic increase in traffic to the cityrsquos major hospitals around that time, and a spike in queries on a Chinese internet for ldquocertain symptoms that would later be determined as closely associated with the novel coronavirus.China did not formally noty the World Health Organization of the new disease until December .Meanwhile, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon stressed that Scotland is continuing to see a ldquoclear downward trend in Covid deaths. It came as she reported seven new deaths in patients known to have the virus, after two consecutive days with none. This was attributed to a ldquoweekend lag in death registrations.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  My post-lockdown dream is a scone in a local cafe  What  39 s yours
story: Our nearby garden centre, a well-run operation, insists on hand sanitation before you enter, and sends customers up, down and across the aisles by luminous arrows, asplaying snakes and ladders. If only it were that much fun. Unable to browse without creating a traffic jam, and surrounded by so many masks it could be a dental hygienistsrsquo convention, all pleasure has gone.Now, we are on the cusp of phase two lt-off, scheduled for June . Unless you are in the shielded category, this will allow two households to meet indoors, or socially distanced drinkers and diners to sup in beer gardens and at pavement tables. Home improvers who have been doodling plans for loft conversions can at last call in the Light Brigade.Around the time schools resume in August, itrsquos likely that there will be a widespreadto something approximating normality. In theory at least. The worry is that,the grim weekly supermarket trip offers any guide, the new normal might feel almost as disturbing as our current lockdown. The sight of medicalised faces, half hidden beneath WWII gas masks or snorkels the constant need to self-disinfect ndash a breeding ground surely for a generation of obsessive compulsives the notices and tannoyed reminders that you or others in the vicinity could be unwitting transmitters of a potentially fatal disease ndash none of this is conducive to a sense of relaxation or safety. And yet, unless there is a surge back to our old ways, the economy will slide even further into the abyss. Itrsquos hard not to feel a moral obligation to help businesses get back on their feet.Some weeks ago, I contemplated what I was most looking forward to doing when we emerged from purdah. Apart from meeting family and friends, top of the list was going for a coffee, closely followed by a day in the library. If to this could be added an early evening drink in the pub, possibly planning our next trip to Italy, I would ask nothing more. What a thrilling lestyle, you must be thinking. Yet Irsquom probably not alone, during these eerily frozen weeks, in realising how narrow and predictable the margins of my le are, and happily so.They say it takes six weeks to form a habit, so perhaps we will get used to the protocols protecting us when we enter the classroom, or train, or go shopping for clothes. It might become second nature to dine behind plastic screens on the bistro table, or to stay three steps away from our nearest and dearest, even in their own homes. And in one respect at least Irsquom looking forward to making my own mask. In winter I resemble a figure in a John Bellany painting, my nose ice cold and red raw. A fleecy face-covering could save on central heating.Even as the danger of infection diminishes, the sobering reality is that fear will persist for a considerable time. To expect to gather in a cafe as we used to, drawing up chairs to crowd around a table, is to day-dream. Almost nothing will be the same as in the good old days, or at least not at first. In the months ahead we will either have to accustom ourselves to new and uncomfortable regulations and rules, or stay housebound.Therersquos little doubt, though, that seeing the ties that bind us being slowly slackened is a huge psychological boost. As yoursquoll have guessed, Irsquom not Melrosersquos answer to Marco Polo. When Ryanairrsquos engines begin to roar, it wonrsquot be me yoursquoll see in the duty free. Yet the mere fact of being banned from travelling more than five miles from home is what has felt so constricting in recent times, even , like me, yoursquore usually quite happy staying within easy walking distance of your door.As we go through the gradual phases of our staggered release, like a barge inching through a lock, simply knowing that we can go wherever we like will come as a tremendous relief. Who careswe must be home by bedtime  Just glimpsing somewhere dferent will be excitement enough. It marks the restoration of a basic human liberty. And, as our leash ens, so spirits will lt. The invisible cordon sanitaire that has been restraining us in will vanish, and to a large degree our lives will feel like our own again.Yet while we yearn to get back to our old haunts, elements of the crisis have shown a better way, which hopefully will endure. The rise in walking and cycling signals a serious cultural sht. Along with the upturn in home deliveries, it might indicate the beginning of the end for the car. Even where I live, in the country, the air is cleaner, the roads emptier, the birds louder. The outpouring of care and concern shown across the nation for neighbours and those in need has strengthened peoplersquos connection to their community. More of us have been shopping or ordering locally, and discovering whatrsquos on our doorstep. Some have been baking their own bread, or cooking from scratch, and discovering the humdrum but satisfying joys of home le. Looking to the uncertain future, a few are on their way to becoming self-sufficient.As we gradually emerge into a freer existence, carrying hand sanitisers the way Clint Eastwood holstered a Colt , one thing seems certain. We wonrsquot take anything for granted again. The simplest of activities have already assumed a profound signicance. To call something ordinary or normal will soon be the highest terms of praise. I never thought a weekend Americano in our nearest cafe would be a red-letter day. Add to that the possibility ndash oh the glamour! ndash of a cheese and chive scone and there, on a plate, is proof of how wonderful le can be.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: scotlands-tourism-industry-set-re-open-business-july-15
story: Assuming Scotlandrsquos strategy to suppress the Covid- pandemiccontinues ontrack, hotels, BBs, as well as pubs, restaurants and museums could all re-open on July , but social distancing measures will need to remain in place.The announcement has been widely welcomed bybusinessesbut the Scottish Tourism Association has renewed calls for the two-metresocial distancing rule to be cut in half in order to further help flagging businesses attempting to recover from the economic shutdown.Traders hit hard by the pandemic could be set for a staycation boom this summer as Scots are given a glimmer of hope of enjoying a holiday at home.Meanwhile self-caterers have stressed they should be able to re-open earlier as social distancing is easier to enforce in their style of operation.Nicola Sturgeon hasstressed that she has not been given any scientic evidence that would justy cutting the social distancing rule in half to just onemetrendash and warned that countries that have taken a more relaxed approach have put stricter face covering rules in place.Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing said that the industry, which has been ldquodevastated by the Covid- outbreak, should be given the go-ahead to re-open at the scheduled review to take place on  July.He added that "some time would then be required for interconnected services such as transport to prepare" ndash with a provisional re-opening date for the sector on  July.: Coronavirus: Social distancing ferry restrictions completely unsustainable for island leThe move is still dependent on public health advice and the ability to move to phase three of the Scottish Governmentrsquos lockdown route-map.MrEwing said: ldquoIrsquove been engaging with businesses since the beginning of the outbreak and I have heard their calls for more claritywhich Ican provide."Businesses should start to prepare for a provisionalto trading ndash with appropriate safety guidelines ndash on  July .ldquoThis date cannot be definitive and is conditional on public health advice and progression to phase three of the route map."Businesses must now use this time to satisfy the necessary regulations and adapt to the newway of living.Guidance is set to be issued by the Scottish Government for how businesses can prepare to re-open.The Scottish Tourism Alliance has welcomed the announcement, labelling it ldquoa hugely positive milestone in our road to recovery - stressing that ldquothe reassurance that there is a summer season for tourism in Scotland will offer a huge comfort and relief to many thousands of businesses.But the alliance has renewed calls for the two-metresocial distancing rule to be reconsidered to help businesses to adapt to the new way of operating.Marc Crothall, chief executive of the Scottish Tourism Alliance, added: ldquoIt remains the case that urgent solutions or alternative measures must be found or taken to overcome the current two-metredistancing restrictions to enable economic viability for many businesses. This is especially true of the capacities on our ferries as it will signicantly impact island economies where tourism is the leblood for so many.ldquoWhilst the package of grant support which has already made available to many small tourism businesses by the UK and Scottish Governments has been hugely welcomed, there remains a good number still in need of immediate grant support to enable them to be in the best possible position to open on  July.ldquoA longer-term support package for the sector will definitely be needed to ensure the survival of many businesses over the coming nine months. Most are reliant on there being an optimum spring, summer and early autumn trading period to cover their costs and fixed overheads in the winter months and recovery projections are still likely to be slow.Earlier at First Ministers Questions,MsSturgeon was pressed by Liberal Democrat MSP Mike Rumbles to think again about reducing the social distancing rule to onemetre.:Scottish tourism at risk of total collapseShe said: "Dferent countries use dferent distances ndash some countries use ametre, some countries use ametreand a half, some counties like the UK advise twometres."All of the advice I have had here in Scotland at this stage says to me that we should not change the twometres."MsSturgeon added: "As you reduce the distance you do increase the risk of transmission ndash theres also a relationship between the distance and then the time that it is safe for people to be in contact."Some countries that have a shorter distance also have dferent requirements in terms of face masks and face coverings.":Nicola Sturgeon: Relaxing two-metre rule would likely need stricter face covering guidanceMrEwing said he accepted public transport will "of necessity be constrained because of the requirement to comply with social distancing" but pledged the Scottish Government will "make the necessary, practical arrangements to do our very best to meet the challenges".Chief executive of the Association of Scotlandrsquos Self-Caterers, Fiona Campbell, welcomed the clarity given to businesses and added that "owing to the nature of self-catering that allows for easier social distancing compared to other accommodation, we are able toto operating sooner than planned, with robust cleaning protocols in place".She added: ldquoScotlandrsquos self-caterers have grasped the task of preparing to open again and in doing so have created our own stringent and thorough protocols for cleaning our properties which we have shared this with industry stakeholders and the Scottish Government.ldquoWe are ready and able to get Scottish tourism moving again.Andrew McRae, FSBrsquos Scotland policy chairman said the news will give traders "an opportunity to salvage a share of their summer season".:CalMac Ferries warns it wont be able to cope with staycation surge amid social distancingHe added:ldquoBut Scottish tourism isnrsquot just a bed for the night. Other businesses in the visitor economy ndash such as tour guides or local galleries ndash can now start making decisions about how and when they should re-open. Tourists will also want places to eat, drink and explore when they get here.Thatrsquos why the plan to re-open Scotland to visitors needs to reflect the breadth of the industry and the views of local communities.Liz Cameron, chief executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce added:ldquoThis will be welcome news for so many who are reliant on hospitality and tourism for their livelihoods.:Council set to take over short-term lets in the capital and use them as homeless accommodationldquoThe Scottish Chamber network alone represents over , businesses in the tourism sector which employ over , people, underlining how critical it is for jobs and skills that the sector thrives.ldquoThe Scottish Government has listened but for some it is already toolateand the challenge ahead remains clear. The sector, which is essential to maintaining the fabric of many areas of Scotland remains fragile. These companies will continue to need support to ensure they can adapt to provide a safe experience for visitors.

title: pm-missed-point-woeful-statutory-sick-pay-levels-mp-claims
story: Stewart McDonald, Glasgow South MP raised the issue at todays Prime Ministers Questions, citing the policy as one of the "most manestly inadequate systems of statutory sick pay in the world".He has now written to Mr Johnson calling for him to cooperate with the opposition on building a better system, after Mr Johnson dismissed his question in the House of Commons.: Black Lives Matters protesters plan to topple Glasgow statue of a former PM - but have wrong manInstead the PM cited the support provided to companies during the coronavirus crisis.His letter, sent this afternoon, states: "Whilst you are of course right to point out the many other avenues of financial assistance open to people during the current crisis, Irsquom afraid this rather misses the point.Even before the lockdown started, it has been clear for some time that the UKrsquos SSP system is woefully inadequate. In comparison to our neighbours in Europe, the UK ranks second from the bottom in the continental league table, only covering around % of a workersrsquo income."In  UK SSP was described as lsquomanestly inadequatersquo and lsquonot in conformityrsquo with the European Social Charter by the European Committee of Social Rights."Only last year the government conceded that up to two million workers did not meet the earnings threshold and we know that many gig economy workers donrsquot qualy because they are treated as self-employed.:Scotlands tourism industry set to re-open for business on July "Even pre-COVID, this was an injustice that required changing. The current crisis has only served to highlight the need for political action."Mr McDonald said the current level of statutory sick pay was "out of kilter" with international comparisons, and said it " financially punishes people for being sick and doesnrsquot give workers the workplace dignity that they deserve."He added: " I wish to press upon you the need for your government to tackle this matter head on. I believe that you will find maximum cooperation from parties across parliament, trade unions and goodwill from millions of workers,the government seeks to level up the current SSP offer."

title: coronavirus-25-000-lives-saved-lockdown-came-week-earlier
story: Neil Ferguson, professor of mathematical biology at Imperial College London, told the Science and Technology Committee thousands of deaths could have been prevented with earlier action.However, he explained that based on what was known about transmission and fatalities at the time, the actions taken were warranted.:Coronavirus: Social distancing ferry restrictions completely unsustainable for island leProf Ferguson said: ldquoThe epidemic was doubling every three to four days before lockdown interventions were introduced.ldquoSo, had we introduced lockdown measures a week earlier, we would have reduced the final death toll by at least a half.ldquoSo whilst I think the measures, given what we knew about this virus then in terms of its transmission and fatality, were warranted, certainly had we introduced them earlier we would have seen many fewer deaths.The UK was put into lockdown on March  in an unprecedented step to attempt to limit the spread of coronavirus.Early in the outbreak, experts had estimated that the number of coronavirus deaths in the UK would be unlikely to exceed ,.According to Government figures, the death toll is around , people but the number of cases where Coronavirus is cited on the death certicate is more than ,. Looking at excess death rates, more than , people have died at this time this year compared to the same time last year.When asked what had gone wrong, Prof Ferguson said: ldquoI think two things ndash one is a paper actually out in Nature, which highlights that around about that time, just before lockdown happened, the first two weeks of March, we probably had , to , infections imported from Italy and Spain, which we just hadnrsquot seen in the surveillance data, until that point.ldquoSo there is much heavier seeding than wersquod expected.He added: ldquoThe key things to determine number of deaths is at what point in your local epidemic you trigger interventions ndash how far in are you when you shut down transmission.ldquoAnd we frankly had underestimated how far into the epidemic this country was, thatrsquos half the reason.ldquoThe second part, which I think would have been more avoidable, is about half of those deaths occurred in care homes.Prof Ferguson continued: ldquoAnd we did all this working under the assumption which was Government policy at the time that care homes would be shielded from infection.He further told the committee: ldquoWe also made a rather optimistic assumption that somehow ndash which was policy ndash that the elderly would be shielded, the most vulnerable would be shielded as the top priority. And that simply failed to happen.Prof Ferguson, whose research helped usher in the lockdown, resigned from his role as a key Government adviser after admitting that he had undermined social distancing rules by reportedly meeting a woman at his home.However, he told the committee he still sits on SPI-M, which advises the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies .Prof Ferguson told the committee that despite border screening at the early stage of the pandemic, probably % of cases imported into the country were missed because checks were not being conducted on people arriving from Europe.Greg Clark, chairman of the committee, asked Prof Fergusonthat was because Sage had advised that it was not necessary to test those people.Prof Ferguson said: ldquoThis is really decisions by the Foreign Office and by the Department of Health and Social Care, not by Sage.ldquoSage recommended that where a country had been identied as having an active transmission, we should check travellers from those countries.He added that the dficulty was that Spain and Italy ndash the source of many infections into the UK ndash had large epidemics before they realised.ldquoWe were just not aware of the scale of transmission in Europe as a whole, Prof Ferguson said.The committee also heard that had the UK had the testing capacity at that stage, then at least screening everybody with symptoms arriving in the country would have given a better impression of where infection was coming from.:Scotlands tourism industry, pubs and restaurants set to re-open for business on July The Imperial College Covid- response team called for a full-scale lockdown in a paper on March  ndash seven days before it was implemented in the UK.When askedhe was disappointed in the delay, Prof Ferguson said: ldquoI said earlier, but in retrospect I would have much preferred it to have been taken a week earlier given that many lives would have been saved.Prof Fergusonrsquos comments were put to Prime Minister Boris Johnson, chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance, and chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty at the daily Downing Street press conference.Sir Patrick said it would be important to look back and see what measures had been most effective, and would be useful in determining what measures to implement in the future,necessary.He added: ldquoSo I think those are important scientic questions to address, and they havenrsquot yet been fully addressed.Prof Whitty said it was important to learn lessons from what had happened in the outbreak.ldquoI think a iety of dferent people are going to come with dferent answers on the timing question, he said.ldquoPart of the problem that we had at that stage is that we had very limited information about this virus.

title: carmichael calls for food standards commission
story: Orkney and Shetland MP, Alistair Carmichael, has called for the creation of a Food Standards Commission in light of reports that food produced to a lower standard could be brought in from the United States under a future trade dealMr Carmichael has said this would result in UK farmers and crofters being undercut.Ministers have previously denied that “chlorinated chicken” and other low-cost foods could be allowed in a new trade deal, but Mr Carmichael has pointed to press reports on Thursday which suggested that the government plans to open up the UK market under a “dual tarf” scheme.A Food Standards Commission, also supported by the NFUS, would ensure that all of the food we eat, either at home, in our schools, our hospitals, and in cafes and restaurants when they re-open, is produced to the same standards of food safety, animal welfare and environmental protection.Mr Carmichael said: “We need a Food Standards Commission now, to ensure that the government cannot undermine our farmers and crofters through underhand policy changes. We are rightly proud in the Northern Isles of having some of the highest standards of produce in the world. Farmers and consumers alike deserve peace of mind about fair standards and fair prices for the food we produce and eat.He continued: “I am astonished that the government has leapt directly from denying earlier this year that lower food standards would be permitted to defending this policy turn wholeheartedly. Undercutting farmers and crofters is not what was promised about the “brave new world” of future trade deals.“It is concerning that the government seems more interested in carrying water for Donald Trump and his #America First# mentality than in supporting our farmers. The government should be accountable to the people they represent, not the whims of US negotiators.”Speaking in the House earlier in the week, Mr Carmichael highlighted the potential impact to farmers and crofters in the Northern Isles: “I would like to hear what the Government’s response is to press reports today that the Government are set to open British markets to food products produced to lower US standards as part of the trade deal with Donald Trump. This was the rhetoric we were given by the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster: he told us that there would never be chlorinated chicken on our plate.“Now, in fact, we hear that as a consequence of the so-called dual tarf process it is quite possible that we will see such products being imported to this country. In fact, we are told that the Secretary of State for International Trade is arguing that these tarfs should be reduced to zero over  years, giving farmers time to adjust to the new “normal”.“For the farmers and crofters in my constituency, it will be a hard reality for them to survive in. Because we are a long distance from the market, we have not gone for mass-produced food. We have sought to improve the quality of the products we have and put into market with a view to export. Tarfs on those export markets will be absolutely fatal to the agricultural interests of the highlands and islands.”Responding for the government, the Paymaster General, Penny Mordaunt MP, said: “I fully understand why he may be sceptical about trusting the government, but trust the people. They value animal welfare, we should trust the consumer and there are massive opportunities for our farmers for rest of world trade.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: how the story of orkney weather spans the globe
story: By Patricia LongThanks to the Rev Charles Clouston, Orkney has one of the longest continuous weather records in the country. At the Sandwick Manse, he kept a daily record for  years, beginning in , and became a recognised expert on Scotland’s weather.After Clouston’s death, the station moved around Orkney but kept going right up until WWII. Magnus Spence ran it in Deerness for almost thirty years,  – . His son, Magnus Thorfinn Spence, was Chief Meteorologist for Bomber Command during WWII. With very neat symmetry, the story now moves to the other end of the world # to the South Orkney Islands. Base Orcadas is an Argentinian weather station but it was founded in  by the Scottish National Antarctic Expedition, led by William Spiers Bruce. His grandmother was Charity Isbister, whose father Caleb owned Ness Farm, Stromness. Spiers Bruce went to the Antarctic as a scientist on a whaling expedition in  and became fascinated by the polar regions. He went on expeditions to the Arctic and, when he couldn’t get there, he went to the top of Ben Nevis, which had snow cover for  days of the year. An Observatory had been built there in  by the Scottish Meteorological Society, to try to learn more about weather patterns. The first Superintendent was RTOmond, the son of Robert Omond from Kirkwall, who became President of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh and Mary Traill, daughter of Professor Thomas Stewart Traill, . Omond was involved with the Observatory right from its planning stages. Ill health forced him down from the summit after seven years, but he remained in overall charge until the Observatory closed in . William Spiers Bruce had applied to join Scott’s expedition to the Antarctic. When, despite being one of the most experienced Polar scientists in the country, his application was rejected, he raised the funds for an expedition supported by the Royal Scottish Geographical Society. The Scottish National Antarctic Expedition of - is not as famous as those of Scott and Shackleton but it has been described as one of the most cost-effective and carefully planned scientic expeditions of the age. As well as establishing the weather station, the expedition brought back a large number of botanical, biological, zoological and geological samples. The house built for the men and their instruments was called Omond House. As well as giving Spiers Bruce a lot of practical and scientic advice, Omond had given a very sizeable donation to the expedition.The Ben Nevis Observatory only lasted eighteen years and only had three observers so it is strange that there is still more Orcadian involvement. According to his entry in the Australian Dictionary of Biography, Charles Anderson, from Moa in Stenness, was the Superintendent there after he graduated in . He quickly realised he wanted to be somewhere warmer and went to work at the Australian Museum in Sydney in , eventually becoming its director.The full version of this article can be found on page  of this week’s edition of The Orcadian. A biography Charles Anderson is available on the #People# page of www.aboutorkney. Patricia Long is a local tour guide based in Stenness, with a particular interest in social and family history.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes release of testing figures
story: The publication of the number of coronavirus tests undertaken by NHS Orkney has been welcomed by Orkney MSP Liam McArthur.NHSO chief executive Gerry O#Brien confirmed, yesterday, Tuesday, that  tests have been conducted within Orkney since testing began, up until June .According to Mr O#Brien, a total of  tests have been conducted in Orkney since the beginning of May. These figures do not account for tests undertaken through the UK Government testing system.Mr McArthur who, alongside the local press, has repeatedly appealed for this information to be released, was pleased that figures had finally been made public.He said: “I welcome the decision by NHS Orkney to publish localised information and provide the public with greater clarity on the level of testing taking place in Orkney.“I have been pressing Ministers for weeks to agree to releasing testing data.  To date, despite warm words, the Scottish Government has refused to budge.“I therefore welcome NHS Orkney’s decision to follow the lead taken by NHS Shetland in making public this information.  As we move forward with ‘test and protect’, other types of information will also be needed to give people an understanding of the situation in their local area.“It is clear that transparency is key to building public confidence and the compliance we will need to see as we continue to emerge from lockdown. This move by NHS Orkney is a good step in the right direction.”NHS Orkney has sought to remind the community that testing is available for anyone over the age of five who has symptoms, and to keep up hygiene standards in order to prevent the spread of the virus.Mr O#Brien said: “It is down to the great work and commitment from all those who live and work in Orkney that we have kept positive results so low, but we must not get complacent.#As the lockdown is being relaxed and people begin moving around more freely, we will be exposed again.“To keep safe, our community must continue to stick to the hygiene and infection control guidelines.”These include:copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: coronavirusShielders may be able to exercise outdoors from June June ,  at : pm vw, px"  The Scottish Government has confirmed, today, Monday, that it will be continuing to advise the nation#s most vulnerable to shield and stay at home until at least the end of July — but that they may soon be able to exercise outdoors.#We are asking people to continue to shield and to stay at home until at least the end of July,# a statement from the government explained.#We will also continue to support those who are shielding until at least July , .#However, from June , , as long as infection rates in Scotland are low enough, we will be advising that those who are shielding can start to leave their home to exercise outdoors. This advice will not apply to those who are shielding and living in care homes.#There will be no limit on the amount of times people can go out, or for how long people can stay outdoors.#A further update is due to be given to shielders via the First Minister#s daily briefing on June . A text message will also be sent to registered shielders on this date.If shielders are advised that they can go outside for exercise from June , the government has advised that they:The government statement added: #We know that, even with this change, shielding is hard. title: tourism sector told to prepare for july 15 reopening
story: Tourism businesses have been told to prepare to reopen from July  — should Scotland move to the third phase on the government#s route map for easing lockdown restrictions.Tourism secretary Fergus Ewing today offered clarity to a sector which has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.However, Mr Ewing warned that #absolutely nothing can be guaranteed# and the July  date may be changed should the COVID- evidence require it to be moved.Mr Ewing said: #I#ve been engaging with businesses since the beginning of the outbreak and I have heard their calls for more clarity, which today I can provide.#Businesses should start to prepare for a provisionalto trading — with appropriate safety guidelines — on the July  .#This date cannot be definitive and is conditional on public health advice and progression to phase three of the route map.#Businesses must now use this time to satisfy the necessary regulations and adapt to the new way of living.#MSPs were also told that travel restrictions are also expected to be eased from July  to coincide with a careful reopening of the tourism sector.It has also been reported that a marketing plan is being prepared by the Scottish Government to reassure rural communities about health and safety measures for incoming tourists.Further guidance will also be published by the Scottish Government which will assist businesses prepare for reopening.Marc Crothall, chief executive of the Scottish Tourism Alliance, described the announcement was #a hugely positive milestone in our road to recovery#.Huge challenges remain as to how accommodation providers, visitor attractions, hotels, pubs and restaurants will operate in the #new normal# but he told the BBC: #The reassurance that there is a summer season for tourism in Scotland will offer a huge comfort and relief to many thousands of businesses.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: unions urge caution as potential reopening of tourism beckons
story: newsUnions urge caution as potential reopening of tourism beckonsJune ,  at : pmScotland#s Trade Union Congresshas sounded a serious note of caution after the announcement of potential re-opening date for the nation#s tourism and hospitality sector.This comes after Scotland#s rural economy secretary Fergus Ewing said that the tourism and hospitality businesses should prepare, within appropriate safety guidelines, for reopening on July .STUC general secretary designate Rozanne Foyer said: “Like everyone , we want to see Scotland’s economy recover as soon as it can be safely and sustainably achieved. The service sector has a massive role to play. We note that there is still an element of caution attached to this announcement and that is vital.“As things stand, we have a contact tracing system, which is at the very early stages of roll-out.  Equally, there is no coherent transport plan and we continue to raise signicant concern of the Government Guidance for its safe operation.“Given that levels of trade union membership in tourism and hospitality is low, along with prevalence of precarious work in the sector,  we will need clear undertakings that employers wishing to re-open will fully consult their staff and admit union organisers and mobile union health and safety reps to support workers.“We will need to see a special Health and Safety risk assessment for each and every establishment that re-opens including viable rostering to ensure travel safety. Employers must commit to supporting contact tracing and not to penalise staff who obey public health guidance.#We expect to play a full part on the task force announced today to guide the easing of lockdown in this sector.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: decision-drop-plans-wider-return-school-summer-disappointing
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.A pupil in a classroomThe Governmentrsquos decision not to require all primary school pupils in England toto the classroom before the summer holidays is ldquodisappointing, the Ofsted chief has said.Chief inspector Amanda Spielman said she was ldquosaddened that people may have become ldquomore frightened than they actually need to be and were looking at the situation in a negative light.Addressing a House of Lords Public Services Committee hearing on schools not reopening more widely until September, Ms Spielman said: ldquoChildrenrsquos lives have been disrupted a lot for a long time already.Her concerns were echoed by Childrenrsquos Commissioner for England Anne Longfield, who said she was ldquodismayed and disappointed by the decision to drop the ambition for a fullto primary school before summer.Ms Longfield said she was not yet ldquoprepared to take no for an answer as she suggested the Government could requisition dferent buildings and temporary accommodation to educate more children.The risk I am most concerned about is that of a generation of children losing over six months of formal education, socialising with friends and structured routinehellip  mdash Childrens Commissioner for EnglandJune , She also called for people who have been furloughed ndash including youth workers, sports coaches and artists ndash to get involved with catch-up summer schools for pupils who had missed out amid closures.ldquoChildren have not been the ones at the forefront of the health crisis but they certainly should be at the forefront of recovery and have a whole range of secondary issues which are very dangerouswe let them lie, Ms Longfield warned.Speaking to the committee, Ms Spielman said: ldquoItrsquos really saddened me perhaps that so many people have become perhaps more frightened than they actually need to be. And that so many people perhaps have been looking at this from the point of view of what they canrsquot do rather than what they can.ldquoI would love to see more people in local areas really stepping up and saying lsquoI could make this happenrsquo and getting as much on the road as possible this side of the summer.She added that remote learning was ldquonot a substitute for classroom experience as children who lack motivation, or who lack a parent to keep ldquotheir nose to the grindstone, were less likely to do work.Ms Spielman said: ldquoWe have to accept that gaps are almost certainly widening and in a way that we simply canrsquot tackle with online-only education.ldquoActually being back in school is the best thing for the vast majority of children. Itrsquos really important.On Wednesday, Downing Street would not rule out the possibility of retired teachers being called back to the profession ndash and buildings being requisitioned to form classrooms ndash to help schools cope.It came after the Prime Minister faced pressure over the decision to abandon plans to get primary school children back in class before the summer break.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said England is the ldquooutlier in ing children to school and hit out at the Prime Ministerrsquos attack on trade unions over the problems in reopening classrooms.Sir Michael Wilshaw, former chief inspector of Ofsted, added the Governmentrsquos approach to education had been an ldquoabsolute tragedy.Speaking on the Today programme, Sir Michael called on the Government ldquoto get its act together and ldquolearn from the mistakes already made.At the Downing Street press conference, Boris Johnson acknowledged he was ldquomoving slower than we would have liked in some areas ndash but he said he wanted all pupils back in classrooms by September.Mr Johnson said school pupils will undergo a ldquomassive catch-up operation over the summer and beyond to get up to speed on work they have missed.He said details of the catch-up plans will be outlined by Education Secretary Gavin Williamson next week.copy -. title: watch star shelties get dressed up for lockdown
story: They are more usually pictured striking a pose around Shetland#s stunning beaches.But the Covid- lockdown has forced Kaylee Garrick and her seven furry friends to find new ways of modelling for the camera.The student paramedic and her pooches have been keeping busy with cute costumes #  some with a Covid- theme.As well as prisoner unorms, several costumes pay tribute to the heroes keeping folk safe and supplied during lockdown # the shopkeepers, delivery drivers, farmers, engineers and emergency services.#Everyone who has kept this world running,# said Kaylee.Before lockdown, Kaylee and her seven models # Shetland sheepdogs Fenton, Thiago, Thorin, Gimli, Murphy and Jara, and an Alaskan klee kai called Ghost # would have been out and about all over the isles.However, since the introduction of travel restrictions, the pack has been restricted to an hour#s exercise near their Scalloway home.#Normally, we#d be travelling around Shetland to beaches and places of interest to get the camera out but nowadays that#s non essential travel and we have to respect lockdown rules,# said Kaylee.#So instead, we#ve been #getting ready# for photoshoots inside, making sure that the second it#s safe to go out again, we#ll have all the props and costumes we need.#It#s actually taken up a reasonable amount of my time and kept me busy in between ambulance shts.#Kaylee makes most of the costumes herself, or repurposes baby outfits, and said it had helped give her something to focus on during the crisis.#Keeping your mind busy in these dficult times is so important and while the dogs have always been a source of happiness for me, I#ve found that lately their presence has been more valuable than ever.#Kaylee#s former photo shoots with her pets have featured in a charity calendar, which has raised more than £, for The Ambulance Staff Charity and Bravehound.She has a  calendar planned # and hopes the videos of her behind the scenes preparations will give people a #laugh online# in the meantime.#I also wanted to show appreciation for everyone working away in the background, particularly those who aren#t getting the recognition they deserve,# Kaylee added.#We would be lost without the postal services workers # their deliveries have been what#s keeping me sane.#The video has had a fantastic response so far and we hope to keep making things like this to keep the public smiling.# raquo

title: calls to save shetland tourism industry with 12 month covid 19 support package
story: Shetland politicians and business leaders are ramping up pressure on governments to provide better support for the struggling tourism industry during the Covid- crisis – and beyond.MSP Beatrice Wishart has added her voice to the growing chorus of calls pushing for the UK and Scottish governments to help the hospitality businesses survive.Ms Wishart#s calls for a -month support plan for the industry follow comments made by isles MP Alistair Carmichael in Westminster earlier this week.At a meeting in Holyrood, Ms Wishart said tourism businesses might survive  just three months without support.She asked tourism secretary Fergus Ewing about working with the UK government to consider a -month support package to tide the tourism and hospitality sector over into next season.Ms Wishart was told the problems had been recognised problems but a -month fund had not yet been considered.After the meeting she said: “In Shetland the tourism season is shorter compared to other areas of the UK. It looks increasingly likely that any exit from lockdown and safe re-opening of tourism and hospitality businesses could be during the low season.#Without financial support to tide them over, that could be the nail in the coffin for many businesses.“In Shetland, like where in Scotland, earnings from tourism during the spring and summer months sustains people through the winter and it is a real worry that coronavirus hit just when the visitor season was starting.#It is clear that a -month plan, at least, is needed to ensure that viable businesses can survive to provide a living for their owners and be ready to safely welcome visitors again when the time is right.”Speaking via video link earlier this week, Mr Carmichael welcomed the Chancellor of the Exchequer#s announced extension to the furlough scheme to protect jobs – but added more was needed to help tourism.“Here in the Northern Isles we particularly see that in the visitor economy, which is crucial to us,# he added.#The assistance for bed and breakfast operators, or operators of self-catering accommodation, leaves too many people without the assistance they need.“A support scheme that finishes at the end of August, or September or whenever it will be, simply will not be adequate in parts of the country such as ours.#Those parts of the country that have seasonal tourism require a -month programme, or  the tourism industry that will be left to be resurrected at the end of this process will be that much weaker, and the rebuilding and recovery that much more dficult.” on Wednesday also heard from struggling tourism businesses.One BB owner said she had been unable to apply for support funds as they required applicants to have paid businesses rates, whereas she paid domestic council tax.Living Lerwick has also raised the plight of small tourism operators.Project manager Emma Miller said that as some did not have a business banking account they had been unable to apply for the Creative or Tourism and Hospitality Enterprises Fund, which opened in Scotland to support the industry. raquo
