When they listen to a particular song, the pair are catapulted back to those carefree days.Dean said: ldquoWhen Eddie began to sing the Men at Work track Down Under, Laurarsquos suspicions were finally triggered.ldquoEddie invited us both to approach a table, where hersquod set up his iPad and told Laura that her family was watching the gig too.ldquoWe made it out to Laura that she was only there so she could wave to her family, but then Eddie told me to pick up a microphone hersquod set down and to take it from there.ldquoI got down on one knee, produced the ring and asked her to marry me. She cried but still managed to say yes.ldquoEddie then sang the song Congratulations as family, friends and neighbours cheered.ldquoIt was such a lovely thing to be part of, said Eddie. ldquoI was only too delighted to help out when Dean texted me and askedhe could propose at one of my gigs.To be honest, though, I was really nervous about the proposal because the last time a guy popped the question during one of my performances in a restaurant I used to own the girl burst into tears, said no and ran off. But, thankfully, that didnrsquot happen this time.The couple, who plan to hold an engagement party in a Belfast night spot when lockdown restrictions are eased, hope to tie the knot within the next two years.Dean says that while it is uncertain whether they will be married at home or abroad, the one thing they are sure of is that Eddie will be there.ldquoAt least we have our wedding singer sorted, Dean remarked..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C June 3%2C 2000
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash Local politicians have this week united to condemn the actions of vandalism in the Ballynahinch area.They are outraged that council signs on several approach roads to the market town have been defaced by youths.The politicians claim that a hard core of vandals have been waging a concerted campaign in Ballynahinch which has resulted in the welcome signs, which feature the councilrsquos crest, being targeted in an indiscriminate manner.In some cases, the councilrsquos logo has been painted over, while in others, it has been completely removed from the middle of the signs.Local councillor Patsy Toman said the attacks being carried out in the town were ldquothe worst possible kind and said the action of a few mindless people will do little to enhance the image of the town.His comments come amid claims that Loyalists are behind the attacks because the council signs are perceived as presenting an Irish image of the town.In the latest incidents, signs at Dromore Road and Lisburn Road have been targeted with vandals blotting out the council symbol, which is a replica of an ancient Celtic cross, found on the hill beside Down Cathedral in Downpatrick.SEAFORDE mdash Down Councilrsquos state-of-the-art landfill site at Drumnakelly is at the centre of a multi-million pound sell-off plan.Council chiefs have drawn up the radical proposal in a bid to secure much-needed finance to help reduce spiralling rates and fund several major capital development projects.The move is being actively considered as one way of reducing the councilrsquos crippling loan charges which have resulted in a steady increase in rates bills over the past number of years.Ironically, details of the plan to sell off Drumnakelly were made public on the eve of the official opening of two new phases at the dump near Seaforde which were developed at a cost of almost poundm.And while council chiefs believe the sale of the landfill site will net the local authority millions of pounds, they warn the plan is only a proposal at this stage and no final decision has been taken.DOWNPATRICK mdash The residents of Down District are to be consulted on the future of the controversial memorial to IRA terrorists erected several months ago in a Downpatrick park.Down Councilrsquos most powerful committee has recommended that a three month consultation period be undertaken before a final decision is taken on the structure which stands on spot in Dunleath Park where IRA commander Colm Marks was killed by police.Signicantly an offer to maintain the memorial has been made by the National Graves Association, the republican body which tends the graves of terrorists all over Ireland.In tandem Sinn Fein is now asking the council to declare the land on which the memorial stands as lsquosurplus to council requirementsrsquo which means it could be sold to republicans.But unionists are warning the sale of the site would create a dangerous precedent and lead to more controversial memorials. Republicans are already planning a memorial on council property in Castlewellan and it is believed that loyalists in Ballynahinch may erect a memorial to dead UVF terrorists on council land at Langley Road.KILLYLEAGH ndash A new community forum, to represent the interests of a wide range of groups in the Killyleagh area, is to be set up.The umbrella organisation will represent what has been described as the ldquoimpressive level of community activity in the area.The idea to create the new group was floated at last weekrsquos annual meeting of the Killyleagh, Shrigley and District Town Committee by secretary Peter Bryson.He said the new group is vital to enable better communication and planning and help with the compilation of joint funding applications to a range of funders.He said the creation of the new group could provide the perfect  on which to develop partnerships of shared interest in the Killyleagh area.SAINTFIELD mdash As the controversy over the dangers of mobile telephone equipment continues, Saintfield residents have found themselves at the centre of the most recent debate.Parents and councillors met in the local library last week to discuss their fears of two telecommunications masts at Comber Road, which they believe are casting a shadow over the local high school.The public meeting was called by mother-of-three Laura Bill in the wake of the independent Stewart report which advises parents not to allow their children to use mobile phones, and pointed to children as being most likely to be affected by possible health risks.Leukaemia is one illness which reports have suggested could be caused, or aggravated by, radiation from mobile phone masts.One woman told Thursdayrsquos meeting that a pocket of seven children under  years of age suffer from childhood leukaemia in the Saintfield area, leading to parental fears that this could be aggravated by the existence of the masts.BALLYGOWAN mdash A shooting incident in Ballygowan during the early hours of Monday is being linked to a paramilitary feud.The house at Comber Road was sprayed with automatic gunfire by four men who smashed a number of windows. One of the weapons police believe was used in the attack was an AK  assault rle.No one was injured during the incident which is being linked to an ongoing feud between the LVF and UVF.A police spokesman confirmed yesterday the gunment made off in a white-coloured Ford Mondeo car which had a taxi sign on the roof.The vehicle drove off along the Comber Road in the village and into Comber where it was abandoned and set on fire at the rear of the Leisure Centre.Detectives investigating the incident have issued an appeal for information and want to hear from anyone who may have seen people acting suspiciously in the vicinity of the house at Ballygowan to contact them.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Members of Edengrove Presbyterian Church in Ballynahinch have said farewell to the Rev Trevor Steele, who is taking up a new appointment in Ohio.Last Sunday morning, Mr Steele and his family were presented with a number of gts by the congregation to thank them for their service and contribution to the le of the church.Along with his we Carol and children Andrew and Joanna, Mr Steele is moving to the United States after accepted a call to McCord Road Congregational Church in Toledo where he begins his ministry next month.Mr Steele has been in Ballynahinch for the past five years after accepting a call to join the congregation at Edengrove while he was assistant minister at Carrickfergus Presbyterian Church.GAA mdash Peter McGrathrsquos job as Down football manager is safe, for the time being. No decision on McGrathrsquos future will be made until August at the earliest.But thatrsquos unless the Newry teacher decides to quit in the wake of Downrsquos shock defeat at the hands of Antrim in the first round of the Ulster Championship on Sunday.County secretary Donal McCormack said there were no plans to sack McGrath.ldquoThe Board has not even started to think about the situation and Irsquom sure Pete hasnrsquot either. I certainly donrsquot see a sacking in the offing, he remarked.Whether McGrath chooses to stay on after the debacle at Casement Park is another matter.This was Antrimrsquos first win in the championship for  years and the first time in  years they beat a Down team.Even the comparatively easy win for the minors, who are defending their All-Ireland title, failed to lt the gloom.Antrim produced all the fireworks amid the violent thunderstorms and accompanying hailstones which only helped batter an inept Down into submission..prettyPhoto

title: Late Coulter strike sends Down into Ulster semis
story: After a number of years in the doldrums Downrsquos footballing fortunes took a dramatic upturn in  when they reached the All-Ireland final. The journey to Croke Park began against DonegalDonegal -Down -ULSTER SFC QUARTER-FINALBENNY Coulter popped up late in extra-time to send Down soaring through to the semi-finals of the Ulster SFC with a magical goal to break Donegalrsquos hearts in Ballybofey on Sunday.Coulter, the undoubted man of the match, struck gold when he got on the end of a sweeping move involving Danny Hughes and Martin Clarke to secure a clash with Tyrone.Both sides started tentatively and Down midfielder Kalum King was yellow carded after five minutes, but Donegalrsquos Dermot Molloy escaped punishment after he clashed with Damian Rafferty.Molloy opened the scoring in the eighth minute with a point from play before both Mark Poland and John Clarke registered wides for Down.Donegal then hit Down for six when Molloy took advantage of some poor defensive play and lashed the ball past a helpless Brendan McVeigh.Down were up against it, but their nerves were settled when Coulter and Clarke pointed to leave Donegal with a - to - lead after  minutes.Poland converted a free to leave a point in it, but Donegal must have thought Christmas had come early when they bagged a second goal when Molloyrsquos shot came off the upright and Conal Dunne was on hand to steer the ball into the net in the th minute.Martin Clarke answered Downrsquos call with a point and this was followed up by a similar score from Hughes as Down trailed - to - after  minutes.Coulter had a good effort well saved by Paul Durcan before Molloy extended Donegalrsquos lead with a long range free. With  minutes gone Poland pointed for Down, but the impressive Molloy negated this score with a point for Donegal.The half closed with Hughes pointing for Down in the second minute of stoppage time with just two points between the sides at the break.Donegal opened the scoring in the second half when Michael Murphy converted a free, but Poland replied for Down with another converted free.Adrian Hanlon, who had replaced Christy Toye, tagged on a point for Donegal to give his side a - to - lead with  minutes left, but Hughes reduced the arrears with a superb point for Down.Marty Clarke left a point in it with a lovely score and Coulter fired over the equalising point in the th minute after good foraging by Benny McArdle.David Walsh fisted Donegal back ahead, but Durcan saved Donegalrsquos bacon at the other end when he twice denied Dan Gordon, who was now operating at full forward.Coulter, who had moved out the field, then fired over the score of the game to bring the sides level with only two minutes remaining and Marty Clarke lofted Down ahead for the first time in the game with only seconds remaining.Donegal had Rory Kavanagh to thank for sending the game to extra time when he pointed with the last kick of the game to make it - to .Coulter scored the first point in extra time and this was followed up by a score from Hughes as Down started to dictate matters.The first period of added time ended with Down two points ahead, - to -.Mark McHugh reduced the arrears within seconds of the restart Colm McFadden brought the sides level at - to -.The game was there for the taking and Coulter was perfectly placed to accept Marty Clarkersquos pass before firing to the net in a dramatic late twist.Eoin Wade replied with an instant Donegal point, but Down held out for an epic victory.Down: B. McVeigh, B. McArdle, D. Rooney, D. Rafferty, K. McKernan, J.Colgan, C. Garvey, D. Gordon, K. King, D. Hughes , M. Poland , P. McComiskey, B. Coulter , J. Clarke , M. Clarke . Subs: C. Maginn for J. Clarke, P. Fitzpatrick for McComiskey, D. OrsquoHagan for McKernan, S. Kearney for Poland, C. Laverty forPoland, R. Murtagh for Garvey.Donegal: P. Durcan, F. McGlynn, N. McGee, K. Lacey, M. Maguire, K. Cassidy, B. Dunnion, B. Monaghan, N. Gallagher, R. Kavanagh , C. Toye, D. Walsh , D. Molloy , M. Murphy , C. Dunne . Subs: A. Hanlonfor Toye, A. Thompson for Monaghan, M. McHughfor Gallagher, C. McFaddenfor D. Molloy, E. Wadefor Maguire..prettyPhoto

title: Laura appointed first citizen during council Skype AGM
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council made history on Monday when, for the first time since its formation, its annual meeting was not held in Downpatrick.Traditionally held at the local authorityrsquos Downshire Civic Centre headquarters, the meeting was switched to Newry Leisure Centre to comply with social distancing guidelines as a result of coronavirus.But only a small number of councillors and officers were in attendance, with the remainder of the districtrsquos  elected representatives and the media following proceedings via Skype.And while there were a few teething problems with the technology, council staff say online meetings will be the norm for the foreseeable future.As revealed by the Recorder in April, Mournes SDLP councillor Laura Devlin was appointed the districtrsquos new first citizen, with Mournes UUP councillor Harold McKee her deputy.Cllr Devlin mdash who said that she was delighted to be the new council chairwoman ndash acknowledged the unique challenges of her year in office amidst the global fight against Covid-.The mum of two described the districtrsquos response to the global pandemic as a testament to the ldquowarm, generous and compassionate spirit that exists throughout the entire community.ldquoThis spirit is found in the local football club, in the volunteer in the food-bank or the inidual looking out for their neighbour, the chairwoman continued. ldquoThis spirit is also found in our healthcare workers, teachers, our tireless council staff and so many more.And Cllr Devlin highlighted the importance of a unied councilrsquos message to the district to be imbued with that same spirit.ldquoWe stand with you and we are proud to do so, the chairwoman continued. ldquoWe will not abandon our businesses that have contributed for so many years to the common good of our district. Together, we have braved the worst of the coronavirus pandemic and the time has come to begin the process of unlocking our district.ldquoThe time has come to unlock the hospitality potential of a district which has never been challenged more than it is at present. Whilst we continue to be and must always be guided by science, we need to prepare for tomorrow.Cllr Devlin said that with international travel for many ruled out, the focus should be on unlocking the district as a premier ldquostaycation destination in Ireland.In addition, she emphasised the need to unlock the potential of local retailers.ldquoThroughout this pandemic, our retailers have provided so much for so many of us and we must support our local tourism providers, food and drink producers, local restaurants and bars and to shop in locally owned retail stores.ldquoAt present, many of them fear that they cannot weather the current storm. Let me assure them that we stand with them and are here for them, said the chairwoman.Cllr Devlin also paid tribute to the work of outgoing chairman Charlie Casey and his deputy Terry Andrews and said she looked forwarded to working with her new deputy, Cllr Harold McKee.The new vice-chairman also paid tribute to Cllrs Casey and Andrews for their hard work, dedication and professionalism in carrying out their roles.And he said while his role will be very dferent compared to that of previous years due to the current situation, he is willing to embrace the challenge and looks forward to working with all elected members across the district.Reflecting on his year at the helm of the local authority, Cllr Casey thanked members and l officers for their support.He said that his year in office had been ldquohugely rewarding and sometimes challenging as he travelled theand breadth of the district from Culloville to Saintfield.ldquoI have visited and hosted scores of schools, community associations, voluntary groups and iniduals and it has been an absolute privilege to see the work carried out across the district, especially by the community and voluntary sector, said Cllr Casey.ldquoDue to the current pandemic we find ourselves in, all of my fundraising events had to be cancelled. However, due to sponsorship from Re-Gen Waste Ltd and other donations I was able to present my three chosen charities, Autism Families, Birthwise and Cuan Mhuire, with cheques for pound,. Each were chosen with the family theme in mind.Cllr Andrews said that it was his privilege to work alongside Cllr Casey and serve the district, thanking the chairman for his hard work and the manner in which he carried out his duties..prettyPhoto

title: Local beaches have best water
story: LOCAL beaches have been given a clean bill of health according to a recent report.Tyrella, Ballyhornan, Kilclief, Murlough, Cranfield and Cloughey have been awarded the highest standard for bathing water quality ndash a prerequisite for attaining the coveted Blue Flag Award.They are among  beaches in the province to have their water quality classied as lsquoexcellentrsquo by the Department of Agriculture Environment and Rural Affairsin .A further nine were classed as lsquogoodrsquo, while three, including Newcastle, were classed as lsquosufficientrsquo.The findings have been welcomed by local councillor Terry Andrews.He said: ldquoThe results are a tribute to all those who work tirelessly behind the scenes all year round to ensure are beaches are among the best around. It is a very worthy accolade indeed.Environment Minister Edwin Poots also welcomed the fact that more than half of the provincersquos bathing waters are officially excellent.He said: ldquoThere is much to celebrate with these excellent results for the quality of our bathing waters, especially given the changeable weather our coastline is often subject to.ldquoWe can take great pride in them and the work that goes into reducing water pollution and keeping our bathing waters clean and safe.ldquoIt is very tempting to visit our lovely beaches, especially when the sun is shining, but I would urge you to think twice.ldquoContinue to protect yourself and your community from the spread of this infection. Everyone must remain focused on protecting the health and well-being of each other as well as protecting our health services, the minister added.The programme to monitor bathing water quality has been in place since , and was amended in , when new standards were introduced which were approximately twice as stringent as the old benchmarks..prettyPhoto

title: Lucy in street cupcakes sale for Alzheimer’s Society
story: DOWNPATRICK schoolgirl Lucy English is a real lsquosweetrsquo heart when it comes to making cupcakes.The  year-old raised pound for the Alzheimerrsquos Society last weekend by making and selling  cupcakes to friends and neighbours.The big-hearted teenager funded the purchase of ingredients for the sweet treats by winning the top prize of a pound grocery shopping voucher in an online competition for the most creative Rainbow of Hope.Organised by social care company, Lydian Homecare, Lucyrsquos large rainbow of hope display, made up from used milk cartons which were then painted, was deemed to be the best entry from Northern Ireland.Lucy, who attends St Maryrsquos High School in the town, said cupcake baking was her speciality.ldquoIrsquove been baking cupcakes for years, said Lucy. ldquoI love baking and I love making cupcakes so when I saw that the Alzheimerrsquos Cupcake Day was coming up, I thought I would try to sell my cakes for charity for the first time.ldquoI made  dferent flavours which were sold for pound. each, but some people were very generous with their donations..prettyPhoto

title: Major boost for tourism as hotels set to reopen
story: THE districtrsquos tourism sector has been given a major boost this week with confirmation that a number of key businesses are set to reopen next month.Hotels, guest houses, hostels and caravan parks are set to reopen on July  mdash subject to scientic advice mdash with Stormont economy minister, Diane Dodds, hinting that some tourism providers could open even earlier.She said Covid- had presented an ldquounprecedented challenge for the tourism industry, as it had for tourism markets around the world.She said the time was right to provide the tourist accommodation sector with clarity about opening dates.ldquoI want to build upon the positive progress in managing the spread of the virus and begin to re-open our tourism industry in a safe and managed way, she said.The economy minister said progress on re-opening will depend on controlling the rate of transmission of the virus and confirmed that further work is under way to assess the potential to re-open pubs and restaurants and all other parts of the tourism sector.The Newry, Mourne and Down Council area relies heavily on tourism, attracting local, national and international visitors, but the numbers have crashed through the floor since the coronavirus lockdown measures were introduced in March.Last week, a number of country parks, harbours, tennis courts and beach car parks across the district were reopened by the local authority, with the National Trust and Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs reopening a number of its local attractions.They include car parks at Castlewellan and Tollymore forest parks, Saintfieldrsquos Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward on the shores of Strangford Lough.The reopening of hotels, guesthouses and caravan parks provides the glimmer of hope their owners have been hoping for, with the focus now in what measures they will be required to implement to ensure the safety of staff and guests.Mondayrsquos announcement by Mrs Dodds will help kick-start the local economy, with the reopening of the key tourist facilities welcomed by South Down MLA Emma Rogan and Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran.Ms Rogan has welcomed what she described as the ldquoroad map to support the tourism sector as part of the Covid- recovery plan.She said the tourism and hospitality sector was one of the worst hit by the global pandemic, with many in the sector seriously concerned about the future.ldquoThe move to allow hotels, hostels, caravan parks, guesthouses, bed and breakfast providers and others to open from July , subject to scientic and medical advice, will be warmly welcomed, said Ms Rogan.ldquoTourism is key to our economy right across the island, particularly South Down. The NI Executiversquos announcement will help those working in the industry to get back to work safely. Indeed, the safety of those working in the sector, as well as that of the wider public, will be paramount in all of this.Ms Rogan said that the reopening of tourist accommodation will depend on the rate of transmission, appealing to people to ensure this can go ahead as planned by continuing to follow social distancing guidelines.She added: ldquoIf we continue to work together, to follow the guidelines and stay safe and save lives then we can get our tourism economy open for business again.Cllr Curran said he was pleased that a major part of the tourism sector was scheduled to reopen and echoed calls for people to continue following public health advice, suggesting aldquochallenging world awaits all aspects of business in the months and years ahead.ldquoTourism is the districtrsquos number one product and, prior to the pandemic, generated hundreds of thousands of pounds for the local economy, helping sustain thousands of jobs, he continued.ldquoClearly, the safety of staff and the public is paramount moving forward and I have every confidence that those who run our hotels, guesthouses, caravan parks and other tourist accommodation will have this at the top of their agenda.Cllr Curran said he concurred with the economy ministerrsquos contention that enabling accommodation businesses to generate essential revenue will help to protect iniduals and livelihoods which support families and communities across Northern Ireland.He said hoteliers and tourist accommodation providers will be seeking clarity of exactly what services they will be able to offer, so that they can plan for reopening with confidence.Cllr Curran recently called for the umbrella group that represents Northern Irelandrsquos  councils to have a role in helping the tourism industry recover from coronavirus and hopes that this will happen.He said the Northern Ireland Local Government Associationshould be involved in the work of the Tourism Recovery Working Group set up by Mrs Dodds, agreeing that the tourism and hospitality sectors have a vital role to play in the countryrsquos economic recovery post-coronavirus.Cllr Curran added: ldquoThere is widespread recognition that tourism will have changed signicantly when the crisis ends, but I believe there are opportunities to build for the future.ldquoSouth Down and the wider Lecale area relies heavily upon tourism and the sector must be given every opportunity to recover as a healthy tourism industry leads to a healthy economy.Financial experts have suggested that % of pubs and restaurants and % of hotels in Northern Ireland may not reopen, but Cllr Curran hopes the estimations are wrong and these key sectors can recover helping the recovery of the local and regional economies..prettyPhoto

title: Meeting for Irish Street redevelopment plans
story: PLANS for the redevelopment of a major town centre site in Downpatrick were discussed at a key meeting yesterday.A steering group overseeing the redevelopment of the former Irish Street police station, a number of adjacent empty buildings and a Newry, Mourne and Down Council-owned car park met to discuss a new brochure which has been designed for the near two acre site.While it was suggested that the coronavirus pandemic is likely to delay the redevelopment of the huge site, traders and politicians are keen to see work starting on the eagerly-awaited economic regeneration of this historic part of the town.The local council and the Department for Communities are spearheading an ambitious regeneration project with the new brochure mdash understood to be still in draft form ndash designed to provide potential developers and other interested parties with an overview of the sitersquospotential and secure expressions of interest.A number of Irish Street businesses have already invested in upgrading their respective shop fronts while the former police base was recently given a fresh coat of paint as part of a revitalisation scheme.The development site stretches as far back as St Patrickrsquos Avenue and is also adjacent to the Irish Street car park, with council officials looking to make the brochure available to the pubic virtually.Described as a strategic and prominent location in the heart of Downpatrick, senior council officials, politicians and members of the business community are excited at the Irish Street sitersquos development potential.While the imposing former police station enjoys protected status and cannot be razed to the ground, it is hoped that potential developers will be able to come with an imaginative plan for the building.It has been identied as a development opportunity site in the Down Area Plan, with the area to the front included in Downpatrickrsquos conservation area.While it has been suggested that housing could form part of any redevelopment proposal, the building has been touted as a potential base for offices.Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities are keen to revitalise Irish Street and hope its redevelopment will act as a catalyst for the wider economic and social regeneration of the town.They are keen to retain Irish Streetrsquos uniqueness where residents and traders live and work alongside each other and ensure that there is adequate parking. There have already been suggestions that an underground parking facility at the current Irish Street car park would allow retail units to be built on top.Work was recently completed on a protracted public realm scheme in Irish Street and it is hoped that the redevelopment of the former police base will complement this project, which resulted in the provision of new granite paving, street furniture and lighting.Downpatrick councillors are keen to see the redevelopment proposal increase the number of shoppers to the town to provide a boost for existing traders who have been at the heart of the townrsquos economy for many years.It is also hoped to regenerate the town centrersquos night time economy with politicians eager for the Irish Street scheme to create a number of much-needed new jobs.Earlier this year, a number of Downpatrick councillors were given the opportunity to view the inside of the former police base and the expansive grounds to the rear.Local council officials say they are committed to working with the Downpatrick business community, residents and other stakeholders on the redevelopment of the Irish Street site and had been planning to meet with them to discuss the way forward prior to the coronavirus pandemic.In addition, the local authority aims to work alongside local people on the redevelopment proposal.Leading High Street brands including Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains have previously expressed an interest in the Irish Street location which is the last large scale development site remaining in Downpatrick town centre. However, it remains to be seenthat interest remains given the current economic climate.Downpatrick councillors say that they recognise the Irish Street regeneration project provides an opportunity to regenerate the town centre and provide a boost for existing businesses and hope that the project can be progressed..prettyPhoto

title: Minister asked to give assurances on bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been asked to make it clear that delivering Ballynahinchrsquos multi-million pound bypass remains one of her key priorities.The appeal has been issued by South Down MP Chris Hazzard mdash a former minister at the Department of Infrastructure mdash who is keen to see work starting on the poundm project.When he was at the helm of the Stormont department, Mr Hazzard signed off the eagerly-awaited bypass in December .Since then, there has been major progress to deliver the near two-mile scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads, with work already completed on a major archaeological investigation along parts of the route.Work was due to complete on the schemersquos economic appraisal before the end of last year, with roads engineers confirming recently that in order to advance the bypass schemersquos state of readiness, preparatory work on contract documents was ongoing to ldquominimise the time required to initiate a procurement competition, should funding become available for construction.The bypass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district, is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with major new roundabouts proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road.Mr Hazzard said while the coronavirus pandemic has consumed much time for all government departments, he does want to diminish Ms Mallonrsquos role in working constructively with her executive colleagues in mitigating the worst effects of the global emergency.But he said since that taking over the reins at the roads department five months ago, the minister has issued statements on electric bikes and hydrogen buses and what he described as ldquoplenty of positive soundings on other capital projects, but there hasnrsquot been a single word on the long overdue Ballynahinch bypass.ldquoThis is a relatively low-cost, yet strategic infrastructure scheme that is shovel ready. Yet it hasnrsquot featured in any of the ministerrsquos public commentary on her departmentrsquos priorities for the time ahead since taking office in January, said Mr Hazzard.ldquoIt is unsurprising then that local businesses and commuters are beginning to question the infrastructure ministerrsquos commitment to deliver this scheme.The MP says he has once again asked Ms Mallon to definitively set out that the Ballynahinch bypass remains a priority for her department and set out a timeline for commencing construction.He added: ldquoIn light of the severe economic impact of Covid- and ongoing Brexit uncertainty, the successful delivery of this project will be a vital step in improving both our local economy and the wellbeing of our local community in these dficult times.In a letter to Ms Mallon, the South Down MP said the bypass scheme is at an advanced stage and is as close to ldquoshovel ready as any other project in the government departmentrsquorsquos capital programme.He has asked the ministerthe Ballynahinch scheme remains a ldquopriority capital project, what stage is it currently at and when will construction work be signed off Responding to Mr Hazzard, a spokesman for the roads minister said that while she is currently faced with ldquoserious and challenging budget constraints, she has already stated that she is committed to working to find solutions that deliver better for communities and improve lives across the North.ldquoShe very much recognises that many in the local community support the provision of a bypass in Ballynahinch, the spokesman continued.ldquoIn finalising budget decisions, the minister is focused on addressing the need to fund essential infrastructure work, promoting a green recovery and getting other strategic projects underway.The spokesman said that in particular, Ms Mallon is considering her long term priorities for strategic road improvement schemes and how they might facilitate complementary improvements to promote sustainable travel choices, connecting people and communities, creating thriving and liveable places that enhance opportunities and our economy.The spokesman added: ldquoThe minister understands the frustration among the people of South Down at the failure of previous administrations to deliver important projects.ldquoShe has already set out her ambition to address regional imbalance with the delivery of projects and hopes elected representatives from across all parties and across the Executive will support her in securing the money to deliver strategic projects which improve both our economy and the wellbeing of our local communities in South Down and across the North in these dficult times..prettyPhoto

title: National Trust sites reopen
story: A NUMBER of local National Trust properties reopen from today.The National Trust has confirmed that Saintfieldrsquos stunning Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward and Mount Stewart mdash both on the shores of Strangford Lough mdash will be welcoming visitors after being closed for a number of weeks as part of the coronavirus lockdown restrictions.In total,  properties are reopening across the province, with Trust officials confirming that advance bookings will be required in order to limit numbers and maintain public safety. They say the reopening process will be ldquophased and gradual.The reopening comes after it was announced that Castle Ward is among the  most popular National Trust properties in the UK.Last week, Newry, Mourne and Down Council reopened Delamont Country Park outside Killyleagh, while the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs reopened car parks at Castlewellan and Tollymore forest parks.National Trust director general Hilary McGrady said the organisation wants to provide safe, local, welcoming spaces for people and, wherever possible, gardens and parks and coast and countryside car parks will reopen.ldquoThe fresh air, bird song, big skies and open spaces people have missed will be there, but things will be very dferent, particularly at first, she said.ldquoWe want to thank people for their patience and support while we gradually begin reopening and welcoming our visitors.The reopening of Rowallane Garden has been welcomed by local councillor Robert Burgess.ldquoI am delighted this tourism jewel is to fully reopen which is good news for people wanting to get out in the fresh air and enjoy the spectacular scenery that Rowallane Garden has to offer, he said.ldquoIt is popular with locals and visitors alike and people will be very much looking forward to ing to enjoy walks along the many trails.Cllr Burgess says he has no doubt that the National Trust will have a programme in place to protect visitors, highlighting the need for people to continue social distancing and practise good hand hygiene.He also welcomed the reopening of Delamont Country Park which is also popular with local people and visitors.ldquoDelamont is one of our hidden gems and a number of exciting proposals have been drawn up to help with the regeneration of the country park and make it even better, he said. ldquoWhile the coronavirus has inevitably halted progress on this, I hope work on this scheme can progress when it is safe to do do.ldquoThere are three separate development phases stretching over the next five years aimed at maximising Delamontrsquos location on the shores of an internationally acclaimed waterway.Initial work includes transforming the way in which information on the -acre park is interpreted for visitors highlighting its wildle, flora and fauna, park events and its links with Strangford Lough.This work also aims to better communicate the history and heritage of the country park and increasing accessibility around the picturesque trail network to improve access to key features and locations.Cllr Burgess added: ldquoThere are very exciting plans for the future and what is proposed is in keeping with the nature of the country park. Funding opportunities are being explored and while this work will also have been interrupted, I hope that it will resume in the near future.ldquoTourism is the districtrsquos number one offering and post-coronavirus we will be relying heavily upon it.Facilities like Delamont, Rowallane Garden and Castle Ward are magnets which help attract people and spending power to our area boosting the economy..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle’s Luke Northern Ireland eSailing champ
story: A NEWCASTLE sailor has become a Northern Ireland champion mdash without taking to the water.Luke McIlwaine was crowned Northern Ireland eSailing champion recently after beating the provincersquos best in a virtual regatta.The RYA launched its eSailing Spring Club Championship at the start of April.Around  sailors competed in their own club championships and eight club champions then competed in the NI final.Nineteen year-old Luke showed his skill by three races and was crowned NI eSailing champion.Luke went to compete in the UK final at the weekend and finished a highly creditable fth out of the ten finalists.Luke said: ldquoThere is definitely no lack of virtual regatta races to take part in, particularly involvement in the regular races that can be played every day has been excellent.ldquoThese races have such a high skill level from all sailors and they are the perfect practice ground.Lisa McCaffrey, RYANI Active Clubs co-ordinator said: ldquoDuring lockdown eSailing was an opportunity for sailors and non-sailors to keep some sort of connection with their sport.ldquoIt has been very popular and I think having these championships is a great way to bring our clubs together and keep members involved with the sport..prettyPhoto

title: Pompey dream
story: BALLYNAHINCH teenage soccer player Eoin Teggart has been given a massive career boost.The hugely talented  year-old has been offered a third year scholarship by Portsmouth.The Northern Ireland youth International joined the League One clubrsquos academy from Cltonville in September  and has blossomed ever since.He made his debut for the academyrsquos first team against Norwich City in the Leasing Trophy as helped set up two goals as Portsmouth reached the final against Salford City at Wembley Stadium.Academy manager Mark Kelly was full of praise for the youngster: ldquoEoin has got plenty of pace and crossing ability mdash now he just needs to hone in on a few things.He is one of three players to be offered third year scholarships by Portsmouth.Kelly added: ldquoThey all deserve this opportunity, but have to get their heads down and be ready to go again.The ultimate aim is to catch the attention of Portsmouth manager Kenny Jackett and secure a place in his first team squad.Before his move to Cltonville Teggart was part of a highly successful Ballynahinch United youth team that went unbeaten for two seasons in the South Belfast Youth League before spending some time at Ridgeway Rovers and Glentoran.He was also part of the County Down side that reached the SuperCupNI Premier final in .On the local soccer front meanwhile, Billy Heal has been appointed as the new first team manager at Dundrum United.Heal was unveiled at the weekend by club chairman Jim McIlwrath and Chris Hogg, vice-chairman and club captain.He takes over from Andy Smyth who will continue with the club as a player and committee member.For over  years Heal has been involved with football within South Down, starting off with the Valley Youth.For the last three seasons he was first team manager at Ballyvea, who led to a double in the Newcastle League.He then took Ballyvea into the Mid Ulster League where they gained promotion at the first time of asking, finishing runners-up to Annalong, and reached the final of the Foster Cup, which has still has to be played because of the coronavirus lockdown.A spokesman for Dundrum United said Healrsquos appointment had the committeersquos overwhelming support and that it was first time a person from outside the club had been appointed as manager.The spokesman said the the club was aiming for a top three finish in the league and winning at least one cup.ldquoBillyrsquos aspirations with Dundrum United are to install a winning mentality and a hard working ethos within the club with fitnesses his driving force..prettyPhoto

title: Schoolboy Fionn in charity walk for Action MS
story: A LOCAL schoolboy is going the extra mile to raise money for charity.Ten year-old Fionn McNulty will be walking from his home at Raholp to St Josephrsquos Primary School in Ballycruttle in order to raise much-needed funds for Action MS.Fionn, who is a P pupil at St Josephrsquos, will be accompanied by his grandfather, James Murphy, a former principal of the school.Fionn is no stranger to supporting the charity. He has been taking part in the Walk for MS since he was in P, following in the footsteps of his mum Joanne, who took part when she was at school.Despite the current lockdown situation Fionn is not going to be deterred in completing his own walk for MS.Fionn has been a top Action MS fundraising pupil for several years and last year he was presented with a special plaque at the annual Walk for MS Thank You Luncheon.The plaque was in recognition of him raising the fantastic amount of pound, which makes such a dference to those people with MS and their families in the local area.A spokesperson for Action MS said: ldquoAction MS recently celebrated  years of the walk for MS but unfortunately, like so many fundraising events, the walks which were due to take place in the spring and summer term have had to be postponed due to the current coronavirus pandemic.ldquoWe are therefore delighted that Fionn and James are taking Action and doing something so worthwhile, which will help Action MS to maintain vital support services to those who need it most.Adhering to the social distancing guidelines, Fionn and his grandfather will be walking from home to the school on Thursday, June .They will be leaving Raholp at am, crossing Loughmoney Road and Ballytrustan Road to Ballycruttle with Slieve Patrick and St Patrickrsquos monument as a perfect back.Their walk will be around five miles in total from one side of the parish of Saul and Ballee to the other. They hope to arrive at the school at pm where they will be met by teachers, pupils and representatives from Action MS.Fionn would like to thank all those who have supported him, friends and family and local businesses including Medicare Pharmacy, Downpatrick, and the Bank of Ireland.If you would like to follow in Fionnrsquos footsteps and organise a virtual event or challenge, walk, run, skipping, garden sports day, frisbee throwing, cycling, please get in touch with Action MS via Facebook or by email at info@actionms..prettyPhoto

title: Walking routes could bring tourism boost
story: DOWNPATRICK town centre could be formally linked to a number of surrounding historical and environmental attractions via a series of new walking routes to help provide a major tourism boost for the area.South Down MP Chris Hazzard has asked Newry, Mourne and Down Council to explore the possibility of developing so-called greenways and utilise old railway lines and riverside paths to help local people and visitors explore areas rich in ersity and history.He said the county town was fortunate to be surrounded by wonderful wildle and beautul nature spots which sit alongside its unique Patrician history which could all be linked to offer new opportunities for entrepreneurs, boosting the economy.Mr Hazzard argued that what the Downpatrick area has is the envy of most county towns throughout Ireland.But he pointed to a major problem mdash the lack of what he described as ldquocommunity infrastructure for attracting visitors that would ordinarily be interested in spending time exploring local attractions.Mr Hazzard said that within minutes of Downpatrick town centre are a host of key attractions of signicant historical interest, including the graves of St Patrick and Viking king Magnus Barelegs.ldquoThere is also the impressive Downpatrick and County Down Railway Museum and the only working heritage railway in the North, stretching out to Inch Abbey and the townrsquos racecourse, continued the MP.ldquoUnder the shadow of Down Cathedral we have the only visitor centre in the world dedicated to St Patrick, with the nearby Down County Museum located in the historic buildings of the th century gaol where United Irish leader, Thomas Russell, was executed in .The MP also pointed to the Mound of Down, Finnebrogue Wood, Quoile Nature Reserve and Delamont Country Park just a short journey away on the shores of Strangford Lough.ldquoTo the east of Downpatrick lies the historic Struell Wells and St Patrickrsquos first church at Saul, a unique site known widely as the Cradle of Christianity in Ireland. But, despite, a large amount of public land and pathways available to link these community assets, these attractions are poorly connected.Mr Hazzard said he has asked the local authority to ldquourgently look at rediscovering the public value of disused railway lines, abandoned riverside paths and overgrown public spaces in developing a Downpatrick greenway project that would help breath new le into redundant community infrastructure.ldquoLinking these wonderful local attractions would also help create exciting new public spaces where people can relax, enjoy nature or exercise, he continued.ldquoDelivering a greenway initiative would not only represent an exciting investment in our local tourism offering, but help create multiple, long-term employment and entrepreneurship opportunities, providing a strong  to build a much-needed, vibrant weekend and evening economy in the town centre.Mr Hazzard believes that developing greenways has the potential to make a huge dference to the lives of local people by providing the opportunity to enjoy traffic free access to fresh air and exercise.He is also confident that the initiative would encourage more workers and children to commute to work and school on foot or by bicycle and help provide a vital leisure resource for local people and visitors alike for generations to come. ldquoThe Covid- pandemic and subsequent lockdown restrictions has exposed the importance of community trails and public spaces to our collective well-being as a society, Mr Hazzard continued.ldquoOver recent weeks, our country roads and parks have been full of people seeking respite from isolation in the green, community infrastructure that ordinarily binds our communities together.However, it is clear that this infrastructure lags well behind many comparative regional, national and international locations.ldquoThankfully, however, unlike most major infrastructure projects which can be quite expensive and take the best part of a decade to complete, community green infrastructure can be delivered much quicker and at much less of a cost to the public purse.Mr Hazzard says he is confident that a new greenway project in Downpatrick represents an ldquoexciting opportunity on so many levels and deserves serious consideration.He added: ldquoI look forward to discussing this proposal with senior council management in the weeks ahead..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. story: NIO minister at the time of Gerry Adams’ internment slams the Supreme Court ruling that cleared the Sinn Fein presidentMan killed on NI farm was kindest person you could meetNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionLettersJim Allister: Unionists on the Policing Board have some questions to answer over the branding and logo sagaHaving sent people out to spin the proposed changes to the Police Service of Northern Ireland branding and logo and found that the tissue paper excuses didn’t stand up to any serious challenge, I welcome the fact that the chief constable Simon Byrne has pulled these disgraceful proposals.By Jim AllisterWednesday, th June , : pm""The PSNI formal crest, and a less formal version that it proposed to use, right. The less formal one has lost the words Northern Ireland and the Cross of St Patrick has lost its colour and so is impossible to recognise as suchInterestingly in mid-May, the PSNI wrote to me asking that I consider withdrawing a Freedom of Information request about the dropping of the words Northern Ireland from their Facebook pages. They claimed that they were unable to deal with the request because of the pandemic. The request remains unanswered. Why did they have time to proceed with this botched attempt to bin the words Northern Ireland from their crest but didn’t have time to answer an FOI request asking about the issue  Are they really that keen on transparency  Letter to the editor " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. title: lord howell after gerry adams ruling parliament must act reaffirm its clear obvious and original intention internment orders
story: PSNI officers due in court after gun fired at house partyMan killed on NI farm was kindest person you could meetNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsUK NewsLord Howell: After the Gerry Adams ruling, Parliament must act to reaffirm its clear, obvious and original intention on internment ordersThis essay by Lord Howell, a minister of state when Gerry Adams was interned in , was written for the think tank Policy Exchange but is published first here. More on the author beneath the articleBy David HowellWednesday, th June , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th June , : pm""David Howell with Willie Whitelaw at Stormont Castle in . The Supreme Court overturned the convictions of Gerry Adams because Mr Whitelaw did not sign off his internment and so he was seen to have been unlawfully detainedIn its recent judgment, R v Adams , the Supreme Court quashed Gerry Adams conviction for escaping from lawful custody. The Supreme Court held that the interim custody ordermade in relation to Mr Adams was not lawfully made. The judgment records that the ICO was signed by a minister of state – but never says which minister of state — and says further that there was no evidence before the court that the secretary of state, Mr Whitelaw, had personally considered whether this ICO should be made. The Rt Hon The Lord Howell of Guildford, who was first elected a Conservative MP in  and has been a Tory peer since  " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...It seems that the case was argued on the assumption that he had not been involved in the decision to detain Gerry Adams. I do not knowmy signature was on the ICO that was made in relation to Gerry Adams. It may have been. The Detention of TerroristsOrder  came into force on  November and I served as one of the ministers of state for Northern Ireland from  March  until  January .While I cannot speak with authority to the ICO that was made in relation to Mr Adams, I do have something to say about how the  Order should have been interpreted and, especially, about the nature of ministerial government, both in general and in relation to the dficult circumstances of Northern Ireland in -. The Supreme Court’s judgment seems to me, as Professor Richard Ekins and Sir Stephen Laws argue in their recent paper for Policy Exchange, to have badly misunderstood the nature and the practicalities of government. in Belfast, at a republican funeral early in the Troubles. Photo: PA Wire" fallback"" layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Gerry Adamsin Belfast, at a republican funeral early in the Troubles. Photo: PA WireArticle  of the Detention of TerroristsOrder  authorises a secretary of state, minister of state or under secretary of state to sign an ICO. As minister of state, I was one of the ministers authorised by that order to sign, and thus to make, ICOs. The Supreme Court’s judgment does not say which minister of state signed the ICO in relation to Gerry Adams. As I say, it may be that my signature was on some of the ICOs made in this period, although they could have been signed by David Windlesham or Paul Channon. Most likely, they would have been signed by David Windlesham as he was specically assigned by Mr Whitelaw to oversee security issues, although we all worked together as a team on all aspects of Northern Ireland’s administration. I note that it was David Windlesham who on  December  moved the motion in the House of Lords that the  Order be approved. He remarked then that “applications for interim custody orders are by no means automatically granted by the secretary of state.Lord Kerr of Tonaghmore, a Justice of the Supreme Court of the UK and former Lord Chief Justice in Northern Ireland, who read out the unanimous judgement in the Gerry Adams case. Photo: Supreme Court PA WireThere is a thorough process of scrutiny before he, or anyone on his behalf, decides whether or not to sign one at all.”It is clear to me that the Supreme Court has misinterpreted the nature and scope of the  Order. The court misunderstands the signicance of Article , which specically provided for a minister of state or undersecretary of state to sign an ICO in the name of the secretary of state.This provision was understood by government in making the order and in exercising it, and by Parliament in the debates about whether to approve the order, to authorise the minister of state or under secretary of state to decide whether an ICO should be made. In so doing, weacted in the name of the secretary of state, who was responsible for the Northern Ireland Officeand the ministerial team and who was, of course, closely involved in many ICO decisions himself, as well as directing which ministers should oversee which aspects of Northern Ireland’s administration.The fundamental failure of the Supreme Court’s judgment is its total misunderstanding of the nature of ministerial and departmental government and methods of operating. A junior minister on duty at Stormont is in effect the persona of Her Majesty’s government and is thereby empowered to act for and as the secretary of state in the latter’s absence. And the secretary of state was often unavoidably absent. In relation to Northern Ireland, it was inherent in the nature of direct rule that the secretary of state had to be frequently in London – in Parliament or the cabinet – and that his responsibilities would often have to be exercised by a junior minister on the ground.On the weekends, one of us was always the duty minister. One minister always had to be available to Parliament, including to answer urgent questions. And those of us who were members of the House of Commons had also toto London frequently to vote .When the order was made, on  November , and when it was approved by Parliament in December , it was certainly contemplated that there would often be cases in which an ICO would need to be made by the minister of state or under secretary of state rather than by the secretary of state himself. The order clearly provides for this to happen. The high number of ICOs that the government anticipated would have to be made, and were in practice made, also helps explain why the order provides that junior ministers may order temporary detention. The Supreme Court’s assertion that it would not have been dficult for the secretary of state to consider each case personally and to make each ICO himself simply does not match the reality.As it happens, almost all signing of ICOs, where the actual signing of the document took place in Stormont Castle, was discussed directly with other ministers and usually with the secretary of state by telephone or message,he had to be in London or his constituency home in Penrith.The secretary of state could not always be directly involved and even when involved in some cases it would often be the minister of state or under secretary of state, in Stormont, who had reviewed the grounds for making an ICO in detail and who was satisfied that an ICO should be made.The minister on duty in Stormont was fully entitled to act in the secretary of state’s name. Other ministers were consulted, to the extent possible, not because this was what the law required, asthe junior minister were simply the mouthpiece of the secretary of state , but because that is how any team of ministers, operating as a team, would act in relation to important matters with political implications for which the secretary of state would have to accept constitutional responsibility.In any case, in relation to Gerry Adams one can be absolutely sure that it would have been discussed most fully and confirmed by the secretary of state before the ICO was made.The political salience and security implications of detaining Mr Adams would have made this unavoidable.I do not know whether there is a record of the secretary of state’s involvement in this case or any other case in which his signature does not appear on the ICO itself. The Supreme Court’s judgment implies not.This may be unsurprising in view of how ICOs were often made, which is to say by a minister of state or under secretary of state in Stormont, with the secretary of state often consulted by message or telephone from London or Penrith, but without a record of that involvement necessarily being kept or now being available. There would have been no reason, and perhaps no capacity, to record the secretary of state’s personal involvement, save in those cases where he himself signed the ICO, because Article  authorised the minister of state to sign the ICO and this signature had itself to be sufficient to authorise detention on the ground in Northern Ireland.But it is a travesty to conclude that because ministers complied with the terms of the  Order, and did not go above and beyond it to somehow record the secretary of state’s involvement, the ICO must now be quashed and the detention ruled unlawful.It is quite startling to see the Supreme Court reasoning that the prosecution had failed in Gerry Adams’s case to prove that the secretary of state had personally authorised his detention. The shape of the  Order makes very clear that an ICO signed by a minister of state or snder secretary of state is the same as an ICO signed by the secretary of state himself and authorises detention. It would have been utterly unworkable for the Royal Ulster Constabulary to have refused to detain suspected terrorists unless and until proof had been provided that an ICO signed by the minister had also been personally considered by the secretary of state. Or for commissioners determining whether there should be continuing detention to have held that they did not have jurisdiction unless and until the secretary of state had provided evidence that he had personally considered whether to make the ICO in question.This would have made the scheme of the  Order simply unworkable. The Supreme Court’s reading of the  Order was not what government intended, or understood, or what Parliament approved. The whole point of the signature requirement in Article  is to make clear who is authorised to make an ICO and thus whose signature on the face of an ICO makes it lawful to detain the person in question.The making of ICOs in -, which the Supreme Court has now denounced as unlawful, was entirely in line with the law, with the wishes of Parliament, with normal ministerial practice and with the immediate security needs of protecting the public from acts of appalling violence and bloodshed . Like Professor Ekins and Sir Stephen, I take the case for legislation to overturn the effect of the Supreme Court’s judgment – to make clear that ICOs signed by a minister of state or under secretary of state were lawful — to be overwhelming. In so legislating, Parliament would be reaffirming its clear, obvious and original intentions and the absolutely normal practices of departmental governance and ministerial responsibility.• Lord Howell of Guildford is the last surviving member of the ministerial team in the Northern Ireland Office, with responsibility under the Detention of TerroristsOrder . He served as minister of state for Northern Ireland from - and as secretary of state for Energy and then for Transport under Margaret Thatcher. He was elected to the House of Commons as an MP in  and has sat in the Lords as a Conservative Le peer since . He was minister of state in the Foreign Office from  to • Morning View: Lord Howell’s paper reiterates need for MPs to make clear the legal position on internment• Other reactions to the Supreme Court ruling below• Prof Ekins: A summary of the Policy Exchange paper• Trevor Ringland: Supreme Court ruling on Adams walked on graves of judges murdered by IRA• Jeffrey Dudgeon: Supreme Court ruling on Adams didn’t reflect violent context of the time• Doug Beattie: Time has come for an inquiry into Sinn Fein, and their relationships with the IRA• Jim Allister: We should be told why anyone thought that Adams was deserving of legal aid• Brian John Spencer: If we are to stop the rewriting of history, we need to say what IRA did during internment• Kenny Donaldson: Victims of terror are dismayed by the Supreme Court ruling• Morning View: A devastating analysis of the Supreme Court’s ruling in the Gerry Adams case• Letter: There is little prospect of trials of republicans• Letter: Many of us in England would help fund civil cases against terrorists——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE Vale of Glamorgan Councilrsquos household waste and recycling centreswill reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but Club, but instead she decided to use her skills to raise money for the charity - Annarsquos Rescue Centre, in Cardf, from where she got her cat, Rocky.Miss Dimech, , of Penarth, took portraits of families stood on their doorsteps locally as a personal project, on Friday May .And she hopes to stage an exhibition when conditions allow.She said: ldquoI had lost all motivation.ldquoMy camera had been sitting in a bag unused for eight weeks and I was getting far too used to sitting in my pyjamas all day.ldquoThe aim was to capture this strange moment in history and to be able to do what I love - get out and take photographs while following government guidelines.ldquoI havenrsquot been able to work since March and photography is a huge part of my lestyle and happiness.ldquoI have been able to create beautul memories for these families.ldquoBack in March our family adopted a beautul family cat, Rocky, from Annarsquos Rescue Centre in Rumney, she said. ldquoWe were amazed to discover how much work this charity was doing in rescuing, rehabilitating, caring for, and rehoming cats and kittens.ldquoI realised that I could use this opportunity to raise some money for the charity by combining my doorstep photography project as a fundraiser."Donations were not compulsory.ldquoDuring lockdown this money is very much needed to feed the surplus cats that currently canrsquot be rehomed due to vets not neutering at this time, but also to help towards any upkeep or vets bills.ldquoMyself and my partner visited  homes beginning at am and finishing at :pm.ldquoWe met some amazing families and thoroughly enjoyed our day out.ldquoWe have plans to attempt one more session in Dinas Powys, Sully, and Barry.She said: ldquoWhen I started the project I was worried that I wouldnrsquot find much to photograph and that it would be dficult to find inspiration on someonersquos doorstop.ldquoI was wrong.ldquoEach family has a very dferent dynamic and portrait photography is all about allowing dferent personalities shine through.ldquoThe images were intended to be natural, raw, and a reflection of the times and I feel that I have achieved that outcome with the help of those who took part.Miss Dimech and her partner allowed  minutes for each household.ldquoIt was amazing to meet so many new faces and to catch up with some of my previous clients," she said. ldquoEach household was extremely thankful and it was a blessing to have that social interaction that most of us have all been craving.ldquoWorking with people is what I do best.ldquoI am a chatterbox who thrives on social interaction.ldquoEach family had a dferent story to tell, some were still working, furloughed, bored or enjoying lockdown.ldquoI met animals, children, grandparents, parents, it was
